         </li>

         </li>

          Master
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Martial_artist" title="Martial artist">
           martial artist
          </a>

           acrobat
          </a>
          , detective, escapologist, strategist, swordsman, tactician, and marksman
         </li>

         </li>

         </li>

         </li>

         </li>

          </a>

      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      <b>
       Batman
      </b>
      is a fictional
      <a href="/wiki/Superhero" title="Superhero">
       superhero
      </a>
      owned by
      <a href="/wiki/DC_Comics" title="DC Comics">
       DC Comics
      </a>
      . The character was created by artist
      <a href="/wiki/Bob_Kane" title="Bob Kane">
       Bob Kane
      </a>
      and writer
      <a href="/wiki/Bill_Finger" title="Bill Finger">
       Bill Finger
      </a>
      , and first appeared in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Detective_Comics" title="Detective Comics">
        Detective Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      #27 (May 1939). Originally named "the Bat-Man" the character is also referred to by such epithets as "the Caped Crusader",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fleisher_5-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fleisher-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      "the Dark Knight",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fleisher_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fleisher-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and "the World's Greatest Detective".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fleisher_5-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Fleisher-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman is the
      <a href="/wiki/Secret_identity" title="Secret identity">
       secret identity
      </a>
      of
      <b>
       Bruce Wayne
      </b>
      , an American billionaire, industrialist, and philanthropist. Having witnessed the murder of his parents as a child, he swore revenge on criminals, an oath tempered with a sense of justice. Wayne trains himself both physically and intellectually and dons a
      <a href="/wiki/Batsuit" title="Batsuit">
       bat-themed costume
      </a>
      to fight crime.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dc-ency_6-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dc-ency-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Batman operates in the fictional
      <a href="/wiki/Gotham_City" title="Gotham City">
       Gotham City
      </a>
      , assisted by various supporting characters including his crime-fighting partner,
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_(comics)" title="Robin (comics)">
       Robin
      </a>
      , his butler
      <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Pennyworth" title="Alfred Pennyworth">
       Alfred Pennyworth
      </a>
      , the police commissioner
      <a href="/wiki/James_Gordon_(comics)" title="James Gordon (comics)">
       Jim Gordon
      </a>
      , and occasionally the heroine
      <a href="/wiki/Batgirl" title="Batgirl">
       Batgirl
      </a>
      . He fights a large assortment of villains, often referred to as the "
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Batman_Family_adversaries" title="List of Batman Family adversaries">
       rogues gallery
      </a>
      ", which includes the
      <a href="/wiki/Joker_(comics)" title="Joker (comics)">
       Joker
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Penguin_(comics)" title="Penguin (comics)">
       Penguin
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Riddler" title="Riddler">
       Riddler
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Two-Face" title="Two-Face">
       Two-Face
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Ra%27s_al_Ghul" title="Ra's al Ghul">
       Ra's al Ghul
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scarecrow_(DC_Comics)" title="Scarecrow (DC Comics)">
       Scarecrow
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Poison_Ivy_(comics)" title="Poison Ivy (comics)">
       Poison Ivy
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Catwoman" title="Catwoman">
       Catwoman
      </a>
      . Unlike most superheroes, he does not possess any
      <a href="/wiki/Superpower_(ability)" title="Superpower (ability)">
       superpowers
      </a>
      ; he makes use of intellect, detective skills, science and technology, wealth, physical prowess, martial arts skills, an indomitable will, fear, and intimidation in his continuous war on crime.
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman became popular soon after his introduction and gained his own comic book title,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(comic_book)" title="Batman (comic book)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      , in 1940. As the decades wore on, differing interpretations of the character emerged. The late 1960s
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)" title="Batman (TV series)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      television series used a
      <a href="/wiki/Camp_(style)" title="Camp (style)">
       camp
      </a>
      aesthetic which continued to be associated with the character for years after the show ended. Various creators worked to return the character to his dark roots, culminating in 1986 with
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Returns" title="The Dark Knight Returns">
        The Dark Knight Returns
       </a>
      </i>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Frank_Miller_(comics)" title="Frank Miller (comics)">
       Frank Miller
      </a>
      , followed by
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Killing_Joke" title="Batman: The Killing Joke">
        Batman: The Killing Joke
       </a>
      </i>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Alan_Moore" title="Alan Moore">
       Alan Moore
      </a>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Arkham_Asylum:_A_Serious_House_on_Serious_Earth" title="Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth">
        Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth
       </a>
      </i>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/Grant_Morrison" title="Grant Morrison">
       Grant Morrison
      </a>
      . The success of
      <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">
       Warner Bros.
      </a>
      ' live-action
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_in_film" title="Batman in film">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      feature films have helped maintain public interest in the character.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-7">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        7
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      An American cultural icon, Batman has been
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_franchise_media" title="Batman franchise media">
       licensed and adapted into a variety of media
      </a>
      , from radio to television and film, and appears on a variety of merchandise sold all over the world such as toys and video games. The character has also intrigued psychiatrists with many trying to understand the character's psyche and his true ego in society.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify">
         <span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (September 2014)">
          clarification needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      In May 2011, Batman placed second on IGN's Top 100 Comic Book Heroes of All Time,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      after
      <a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">
       Superman
      </a>
      .
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Empire_(magazine)" title="Empire (magazine)">
        Empire
       </a>
      </i>
      magazine listed him second in their 50 Greatest Comic Book Characters of All Time. The character has been portrayed in films by
      <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Wilson" title="Lewis Wilson">
       Lewis Wilson
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Lowery_(actor)" title="Robert Lowery (actor)">
       Robert Lowery
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Adam_West" title="Adam West">
       Adam West
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Keaton" title="Michael Keaton">
       Michael Keaton
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Conroy" title="Kevin Conroy">
       Kevin Conroy
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Val_Kilmer" title="Val Kilmer">
       Val Kilmer
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/George_Clooney" title="George Clooney">
       George Clooney
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Christian_Bale" title="Christian Bale">
       Christian Bale
      </a>
      , and by
      <a href="/wiki/Ben_Affleck" title="Ben Affleck">
       Ben Affleck
      </a>
      in the 2016 movie,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_v_Superman:_Dawn_of_Justice" title="Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice">
        Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Publication_history">
       Publication history
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Batman_comics" title="List of Batman comics">
       List of Batman comics
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Creation">
       Creation
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In early 1939, the success of
      <a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">
       Superman
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Action_Comics" title="Action Comics">
        Action Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      prompted editors at the comic book division of
      <a href="/wiki/National_Publications" title="National Publications">
       National Publications
      </a>
      (the future DC Comics) to request more superheroes for its titles. In response,
      <a href="/wiki/Bob_Kane" title="Bob Kane">
       Bob Kane
      </a>
      created "the Bat-Man."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Collaborator
      <a href="/wiki/Bill_Finger" title="Bill Finger">
       Bill Finger
      </a>
      recalled "Kane had an idea for a character called 'Batman', and he'd like me to see the drawings. I went over to Kane's, and he had drawn a character who looked very much like Superman with kind of ... reddish tights, I believe, with boots ... no gloves, no gauntlets ... with a small
      <a href="/wiki/Domino_mask" title="Domino mask">
       domino mask
      </a>
      , swinging on a rope. He had two stiff wings that were sticking out, looking like bat wings. And under it was a big sign ... BATMAN."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
       <a href="#cite_note-10">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        10
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The bat wing like cape was suggested by Bob Kane; who was inspired by seeing
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonardo_Da_Vinci" title="Leonardo Da Vinci">
       Leonardo Da Vinci
      </a>
      's sketch of an
      <a href="/wiki/Ornithopter" title="Ornithopter">
       ornithopter
      </a>
      flying device as a child.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Finger offered such suggestions as giving the character a
      <a href="/wiki/Cowl" title="Cowl">
       cowl
      </a>
      instead of a simple domino mask, a cape instead of wings, and gloves, and removing the red sections from the original costume.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Archives_3_14-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Archives_3-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        15
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Finger said he devised the name Bruce Wayne for the character's secret identity: "Bruce Wayne's first name came from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robert_I_of_Scotland" title="Robert I of Scotland">
       Robert Bruce
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">
       Scottish
      </a>
      patriot. Bruce, being a playboy, was a man of gentry. I searched for a name that would suggest colonialism. I tried Adams, Hancock ... then I thought of
      <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Wayne" title="Anthony Wayne">
       Mad Anthony Wayne
      </a>
      ."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-creation_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-creation-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He later said his suggestions were influenced by
      <a href="/wiki/Lee_Falk" title="Lee Falk">
       Lee Falk
      </a>
      's popular
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Phantom" title="The Phantom">
        The Phantom
       </a>
      </i>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Print_syndication" title="Print syndication">
       syndicated
      </a>
      newspaper comic-strip character with which Kane was familiar as well.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Kane and Finger drew upon contemporary 1930s popular culture for inspiration regarding much of the Bat-Man's look, personality, methods and weaponry. Details find predecessors in
      <a href="/wiki/Pulp_magazine" title="Pulp magazine">
       pulp fiction
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">
       comic strips
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Newspaper" title="Newspaper">
       newspaper
      </a>
      headlines, and autobiographical details referring to Kane himself.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As an aristocratic hero with a double identity, the Bat-Man had predecessors in the
      <a href="/wiki/The_Scarlet_Pimpernel" title="The Scarlet Pimpernel">
       Scarlet Pimpernel
      </a>
      (created by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baroness_Emmuska_Orczy" title="Baroness Emmuska Orczy">
       Baroness Emmuska Orczy
      </a>
      , 1903) and
      <a href="/wiki/Zorro" title="Zorro">
       Zorro
      </a>
      (created by
      <a href="/wiki/Johnston_McCulley" title="Johnston McCulley">
       Johnston McCulley
      </a>
      , 1919). Like them, he performed his heroic deeds in secret, averted suspicion by playing the fool in public, and marked his work with a signature symbol. Kane specifically noted the influence of the films
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Mark_of_Zorro_(1920_film)" title="The Mark of Zorro (1920 film)">
        The Mark of Zorro
       </a>
      </i>
      (1920) and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Bat_Whispers" title="The Bat Whispers">
        The Bat Whispers
       </a>
      </i>
      (1930) in the creation of the character's iconography. Finger, drawing inspiration from pulp heroes like
      <a href="/wiki/Doc_Savage" title="Doc Savage">
       Doc Savage
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/The_Shadow" title="The Shadow">
       The Shadow
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Tracy" title="Dick Tracy">
       Dick Tracy
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">
       Sherlock Holmes
      </a>
      , made the character a master sleuth.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
       <a href="#cite_note-19">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        19
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        20
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In his 1989 autobiography, Kane detailed Finger's contributions to Batman's creation:
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       One day I called Bill and said, 'I have a new character called the Bat-Man and I've made some crude, elementary sketches I'd like you to look at'. He came over and I showed him the drawings. At the time, I only had a small domino mask, like the one Robin later wore, on Batman's face. Bill said, 'Why not make him look more like a bat and put a hood on him, and take the eyeballs out and just put slits for eyes to make him look more mysterious?' At this point, the Bat-Man wore a red union suit; the wings, trunks, and mask were black. I thought that red and black would be a good combination. Bill said that the costume was too bright: 'Color it dark gray to make it look more ominous'. The cape looked like two stiff bat wings attached to his arms. As Bill and I talked, we realized that these wings would get cumbersome when Bat-Man was in action, and changed them into a cape, scalloped to look like bat wings when he was fighting or swinging down on a rope. Also, he didn't have any gloves on, and we added them so that he wouldn't leave fingerprints.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_17-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-17">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         17
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Subsequent_creation_credit">
       Subsequent creation credit
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Kane signed away ownership in the character in exchange for, among other compensation, a mandatory byline on all Batman comics. This byline did not, originally say "Batman created by Bob Kane"; his name was simply written on the title page of each story. The name disappeared from the comic book in the mid-1960s, replaced by credits for each story's actual writer and artists. In the late 1970s, when
      <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Siegel" title="Jerry Siegel">
       Jerry Siegel
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Shuster" title="Joe Shuster">
       Joe Shuster
      </a>
      began receiving a "created by" credit on the Superman titles, along with
      <a href="/wiki/William_Moulton_Marston" title="William Moulton Marston">
       William Moulton Marston
      </a>
      being given the byline for creating
      <a href="/wiki/Wonder_Woman" title="Wonder Woman">
       Wonder Woman
      </a>
      , Batman stories began saying "Created by Bob Kane" in addition to the other credits.
     </p>
     <p>
      Finger did not receive the same recognition. While he had received credit for other DC work since the 1940s, he began, in the 1960s, to receive limited acknowledgment for his Batman writing; in the letters page of
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #169 (February 1965) for example, editor
      <a href="/wiki/Julius_Schwartz" title="Julius Schwartz">
       Julius Schwartz
      </a>
      names him as the creator of the
      <a href="/wiki/Riddler" title="Riddler">
       Riddler
      </a>
      , one of Batman's recurring villains. However, Finger's contract left him only with his writing page rate and no byline. Kane wrote, "Bill was disheartened by the lack of major accomplishments in his career. He felt that he had not used his creative potential to its fullest and that success had passed him by."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-creation_16-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-creation-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the time of Finger's death in 1974, DC had not officially credited Finger as Batman co-creator.
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Robinson" title="Jerry Robinson">
       Jerry Robinson
      </a>
      , who also worked with Finger and Kane on the strip at this time, has criticized Kane for failing to share the credit. He recalled Finger resenting his position, stating in a 2005 interview with
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Comics_Journal" title="The Comics Journal">
        The Comics Journal
       </a>
      </i>
      :
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       Bob made him more insecure, because while he slaved working on Batman, he wasn't sharing in any of the glory or the money that Bob began to make, which is why... [he was] going to leave [Kane's employ]. ... [Kane] should have credited Bill as co-creator, because I know; I was there. ... That was one thing I would never forgive Bob for, was not to take care of Bill or recognize his vital role in the creation of Batman. As with Siegel and Shuster, it should have been the same, the same co-creator credit in the strip, writer and artist.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         21
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      Although Kane initially rebutted Finger's claims at having created the character, writing in a 1965 open letter to fans that "it seemed to me that Bill Finger has given out the impression that he and not myself created the ''Batman, t'  [
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Sic" title="Sic">
        sic
       </a>
      </i>
      ] as well as Robin and all the other leading villains and characters. This statement is fraudulent and entirely untrue." Kane himself also commented on Finger's lack of credit. "The trouble with being a 'ghost' writer or artist is that you must remain rather anonymously without 'credit'. However, if one wants the 'credit', then one has to cease being a 'ghost' or follower and become a leader or innovator."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1989, Kane revisited Finger's situation, recalling in an interview,
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       In those days it was like, one artist and he had his name over it [the comic strip]  the policy of DC in the comic books was, if you can't write it, obtain other writers, but their names would never appear on the comic book in the finished version. So Bill never asked me for it [the byline] and I never volunteered  I guess my ego at that time. And I felt badly, really, when he [Finger] died.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
        <a href="#cite_note-23">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         23
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">
       Early years
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Detective_Comics_27.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="419" data-file-width="300" height="307" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a8/Detective_Comics_27.jpg/220px-Detective_Comics_27.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a8/Detective_Comics_27.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a8/Detective_Comics_27.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Detective_Comics_27.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Batman made his debut in
        <i>
         Detective Comics
        </i>
        #27 (May 1939). Cover art by
        <a href="/wiki/Bob_Kane" title="Bob Kane">
         Bob Kane
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The first Batman story, "The Case of the Chemical Syndicate," was published in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #27 (May 1939). Finger said, "Batman was originally written in the style of the pulps,"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        24
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and this influence was evident with Batman showing little remorse over killing or maiming criminals. Batman proved a hit character, and he received his own solo title in 1940, while continuing to star in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      . By that time, National was the top-selling and most influential publisher in the industry; Batman and the company's other major hero, Superman, were the cornerstones of the company's success.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The two characters were featured side-by-side as the stars of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Finest_Comics" title="World's Finest Comics">
        World's Finest Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      , which was originally titled
      <i>
       World's Best Comics
      </i>
      when it debuted in fall 1940. Creators including
      <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Robinson" title="Jerry Robinson">
       Jerry Robinson
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Sprang" title="Dick Sprang">
       Dick Sprang
      </a>
      also worked on the strips during this period.
     </p>
     <p>
      Over the course of the first few Batman strips elements were added to the character and the artistic depiction of Batman evolved. Kane noted that within six issues he drew the character's jawline more pronounced, and lengthened the ears on the costume. "About a year later he was almost the full figure, my mature Batman," Kane said.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vapzdg_26-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-vapzdg-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Batman%27s_utility_belt" title="Batman's utility belt">
       Batman's characteristic utility belt
      </a>
      was introduced in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #29 (July 1939), followed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Boomerang" title="Boomerang">
       boomerang
      </a>
      -like batarang and the first bat-themed vehicle, the
      <a href="/wiki/Batplane" title="Batplane">
       Batplane
      </a>
      , in #31 (Sept. 1939). The character's origin was revealed in #33 (Nov. 1939), unfolding in a two-page story that establishes the brooding persona of Batman, a character driven by the death of his parents. Written by Finger, it depicts a young Bruce Wayne witnessing his parents' murder at the hands of a mugger. Days later, at their grave, the child vows that "by the spirits of my parents [I will] avenge their deaths by spending the rest of my life warring on all criminals."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The early, pulp-inflected portrayal of Batman started to soften in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #38 (April 1940) with the introduction of
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_(comics)" title="Robin (comics)">
       Robin
      </a>
      , Batman's kid sidekick.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_p17_30-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wright_p17-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Robin was introduced, based on Finger's suggestion Batman needed a "
      <a href="/wiki/Dr._Watson" title="Dr. Watson">
       Watson
      </a>
      " with whom Batman could talk.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sales nearly doubled, despite Kane's preference for a solo Batman, and it sparked a proliferation of "kid sidekicks."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first issue of the solo spin-off series
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(comic_book)" title="Batman (comic book)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      was notable not only for introducing two of his most persistent enemies, the
      <a href="/wiki/Joker_(comics)" title="Joker (comics)">
       Joker
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Catwoman" title="Catwoman">
       Catwoman
      </a>
      , but for a story in which Batman shoots some monstrous giants to death. That story prompted editor
      <a href="/wiki/Whitney_Ellsworth" title="Whitney Ellsworth">
       Whitney Ellsworth
      </a>
      to decree that the character could no longer kill or use a gun.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dan42_33-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-dan42-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      By 1942, the writers and artists behind the Batman comics had established most of the basic elements of the Batman mythos.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boichel_p9_34-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Boichel_p9-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the years following World War II, DC Comics "adopted a postwar editorial direction that increasingly de-emphasized social commentary in favor of lighthearted juvenile fantasy." The impact of this editorial approach was evident in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      comics of the postwar period; removed from the "bleak and menacing world" of the strips of the early 1940s, Batman was instead portrayed as a respectable citizen and paternal figure that inhabited a "bright and colorful" environment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        35
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="1950s_and_early_1960s">
       1950s and early 1960s
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Batman was one of the few superhero characters to be continuously published as interest in the genre waned during the 1950s. In the story "The Mightiest Team in the World" in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Superman_(comic_book)" title="Superman (comic book)">
        Superman
       </a>
      </i>
      #76 (June 1952), Batman teams up with Superman for the first time and the pair discovers each other's secret identity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        36
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following the success of this story,
      <i>
       World's Finest Comics
      </i>
      was revamped so it featured stories starring both heroes together, instead of the separate Batman and Superman features that had been running before.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
       <a href="#cite_note-37">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        37
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The team-up of the characters was "a financial success in an era when those were few and far between";
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        38
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      this series of stories ran until the book's cancellation in 1986.
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman comics were among those criticized when the comic book industry came under scrutiny with the publication of psychologist
      <a href="/wiki/Fredric_Wertham" title="Fredric Wertham">
       Fredric Wertham
      </a>
      's book
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Seduction_of_the_Innocent" title="Seduction of the Innocent">
        Seduction of the Innocent
       </a>
      </i>
      in 1954. Wertham's thesis was that children imitated crimes committed in comic books, and that these works corrupt the morals of the youth. Wertham criticized Batman comics for their supposed
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homosexual" title="Homosexual">
       homosexual
      </a>
      overtones and argued that Batman and Robin were portrayed as lovers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        39
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Wertham's criticisms raised a public outcry during the 1950s, eventually leading to the establishment of the
      <a href="/wiki/Comics_Code_Authority" title="Comics Code Authority">
       Comics Code Authority
      </a>
      . The tendency towards a "sunnier Batman" in the postwar years intensified after the introduction of the Comics Code.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        40
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Scholars have suggested that the characters of
      <a href="/wiki/Batwoman" title="Batwoman">
       Batwoman
      </a>
      (in 1956) and the pre-
      <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Gordon" title="Barbara Gordon">
       Barbara Gordon
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Bette_Kane" title="Bette Kane">
       Bat-Girl
      </a>
      (in 1961) were introduced in part to refute the allegation that Batman and Robin were gay, and the stories took on a campier, lighter feel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        41
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the late 1950s, Batman stories gradually became more science fiction-oriented, an attempt at mimicking the success of other DC characters that had dabbled in the genre.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        42
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      New characters such as Batwoman,
      <a href="/wiki/Ace_the_Bat-Hound" title="Ace the Bat-Hound">
       Ace the Bat-Hound
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Bat-Mite" title="Bat-Mite">
       Bat-Mite
      </a>
      were introduced. Batman's adventures often involved odd transformations or bizarre space aliens. In 1960, Batman debuted as a member of the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_League" title="Justice League">
       Justice League of America
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Brave_and_the_Bold" title="The Brave and the Bold">
        The Brave and the Bold
       </a>
      </i>
      #28 (Feb. 1960), and went on to appear in several Justice League comic series starting later that same year.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id=".22New_Look.22_Batman_and_camp">
       "New Look" Batman and camp
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      By 1964, sales on Batman titles had fallen drastically. Bob Kane noted that, as a result, DC was "planning to kill Batman off altogether."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
       <a href="#cite_note-43">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        43
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In response to this, editor
      <a href="/wiki/Julius_Schwartz" title="Julius Schwartz">
       Julius Schwartz
      </a>
      was assigned to the Batman titles. He presided over drastic changes, beginning with 1964's
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #327 (May 1964), which was cover-billed as the "New Look". Schwartz introduced changes designed to make Batman more contemporary, and to return him to more detective-oriented stories. He brought in artist
      <a href="/wiki/Carmine_Infantino" title="Carmine Infantino">
       Carmine Infantino
      </a>
      to help overhaul the character. The
      <a href="/wiki/Batmobile" title="Batmobile">
       Batmobile
      </a>
      was redesigned, and Batman's costume was modified to incorporate a yellow ellipse behind the bat-insignia. The space aliens, time travel, and characters of the 1950s such as Batwoman, Ace, and Bat-Mite were retired. Batman's butler Alfred was killed off (though his death was quickly reversed) while a new female relative for the Wayne family, Aunt Harriet, came to live with Bruce Wayne and Dick Grayson.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        44
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The debut of the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)" title="Batman (TV series)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      television series in 1966 had a profound influence on the character. The success of the series increased sales throughout the comic book industry, and
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      reached a circulation of close to 900,000 copies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        45
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Elements such as the character of
      <a href="/wiki/Batgirl" title="Batgirl">
       Batgirl
      </a>
      and the show's
      <a href="/wiki/Camp_(style)" title="Camp (style)">
       campy
      </a>
      nature were introduced into the comics; the series also initiated the return of Alfred. Although both the comics and TV show were successful for a time, the camp approach eventually wore thin and the show was canceled in 1968. In the aftermath, the Batman comics themselves lost popularity once again. As Julius Schwartz noted, "When the television show was a success, I was asked to be campy, and of course when the show faded, so did the comic books."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
       <a href="#cite_note-46">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        46
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Starting in 1969, writer
      <a href="/wiki/Dennis_O%27Neil" title="Dennis O'Neil">
       Dennis O'Neil
      </a>
      and artist
      <a href="/wiki/Neal_Adams" title="Neal Adams">
       Neal Adams
      </a>
      made a deliberate effort to distance Batman from the campy portrayal of the 1960s TV series and to return the character to his roots as a "grim avenger of the night."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        47
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      O'Neil said his idea was "simply to take it back to where it started. I went to the DC library and read some of the early stories. I tried to get a sense of what Kane and Finger were after."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
       <a href="#cite_note-48">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        48
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      O'Neil and Adams first collaborated on the story "
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=The_Secret_of_the_Waiting_Graves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="The Secret of the Waiting Graves (page does not exist)">
       The Secret of the Waiting Graves
      </a>
      " (
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #395, January 1970). Few stories were true collaborations between O'Neil, Adams, Schwartz, and inker
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Giordano" title="Dick Giordano">
       Dick Giordano
      </a>
      , and in actuality these men were mixed and matched with various other creators during the 1970s; nevertheless the influence of their work was "tremendous."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        49
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Giordano said: "We went back to a grimmer, darker Batman, and I think that's why these stories did so well..."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        50
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      While the work of O'Neil and Adams was popular with fans, the acclaim did little to improve declining sales; the same held true with a similarly acclaimed run by writer
      <a href="/wiki/Steve_Englehart" title="Steve Englehart">
       Steve Englehart
      </a>
      and penciler
      <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Rogers" title="Marshall Rogers">
       Marshall Rogers
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #471476 (August 1977 April 1978), which went on to influence the 1989 movie
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      and be adapted for
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Animated_Series" title="Batman: The Animated Series">
        Batman: The Animated Series
       </a>
      </i>
      , which debuted in 1992.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        51
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Regardless, circulation continued to drop through the 1970s and 1980s, hitting an all-time low in 1985.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        52
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="The_Dark_Knight_Returns">
       <i>
        The Dark Knight Returns
       </i>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Alternative_versions_of_Batman" title="Alternative versions of Batman">
       Alternative versions of Batman
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Frank_Miller_(comics)" title="Frank Miller (comics)">
       Frank Miller
      </a>
      's limited series
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Returns" title="The Dark Knight Returns">
        The Dark Knight Returns
       </a>
      </i>
      (FebruaryJune 1986), which tells the story of a 55-year old Batman coming out of retirement in a possible future, reinvigorated the character.
      <i>
       The Dark Knight Returns
      </i>
      was a financial success and has since become one of the medium's most noted touchstones.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
       <a href="#cite_note-53">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        53
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The series also sparked a major resurgence in the character's popularity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        54
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      That year Dennis O'Neil took over as editor of the Batman titles and set the template for the portrayal of Batman following DC's status quo-altering miniseries
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Crisis_on_Infinite_Earths" title="Crisis on Infinite Earths">
        Crisis on Infinite Earths
       </a>
      </i>
      . O'Neil operated under the assumption that he was hired to revamp the character and as a result tried to instill a different tone in the books than had gone before.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        55
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      One outcome of this new approach was the "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Year_One" title="Batman: Year One">
       Year One
      </a>
      " storyline in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #404407 (FebruaryMay 1987), in which Frank Miller and artist
      <a href="/wiki/David_Mazzucchelli" title="David Mazzucchelli">
       David Mazzucchelli
      </a>
      redefined the character's origins. Writer
      <a href="/wiki/Alan_Moore" title="Alan Moore">
       Alan Moore
      </a>
      and artist
      <a href="/wiki/Brian_Bolland" title="Brian Bolland">
       Brian Bolland
      </a>
      continued this dark trend with 1988's 48-page
      <a href="/wiki/One-shot_(comics)" title="One-shot (comics)">
       one-shot
      </a>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Killing_Joke" title="Batman: The Killing Joke">
        Batman: The Killing Joke
       </a>
      </i>
      , in which the Joker, attempting to drive
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commissioner_Gordon" title="Commissioner Gordon">
       Commissioner Gordon
      </a>
      insane, cripples Gordon's daughter
      <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Gordon" title="Barbara Gordon">
       Barbara
      </a>
      , and then kidnaps and tortures the commissioner, physically and psychologically.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dark_knight_returns.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="450" data-file-width="300" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/77/Dark_knight_returns.jpg/170px-Dark_knight_returns.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/77/Dark_knight_returns.jpg/255px-Dark_knight_returns.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/7/77/Dark_knight_returns.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dark_knight_returns.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The first issue of
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Returns" title="The Dark Knight Returns">
          The Dark Knight Returns
         </a>
        </i>
        , which redefined Batman in the 1980s. Cover art by
        <a href="/wiki/Frank_Miller_(comics)" title="Frank Miller (comics)">
         Frank Miller
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Batman comics garnered major attention in 1988 when DC Comics created a
      <a href="/wiki/Premium-rate_telephone_number" title="Premium-rate telephone number">
       900 number
      </a>
      for readers to call to vote on whether
      <a href="/wiki/Jason_Todd" title="Jason Todd">
       Jason Todd
      </a>
      , the second Robin, lived or died. Voters decided in favor of Jason's death by a narrow margin of 28 votes (see
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_A_Death_in_the_Family" title="Batman: A Death in the Family">
        Batman: A Death in the Family
       </a>
      </i>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        56
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The following year saw the release of
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Burton" title="Tim Burton">
       Tim Burton
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(1989_film)" title="Batman (1989 film)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      feature film, which firmly brought the character back to the public's attention, grossing millions of dollars at the box office, and millions more in merchandising. However, the three sequels, Tim Burton's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Returns" title="Batman Returns">
        Batman Returns
       </a>
      </i>
      and director
      <a href="/wiki/Joel_Schumacher" title="Joel Schumacher">
       Joel Schumacher
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Forever" title="Batman Forever">
        Batman Forever
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_%26_Robin_(film)" title="Batman &amp; Robin (film)">
        Batman &amp; Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      , did not perform as well at the box office. The fourth film in the series, the Schumacher-directed
      <i>
       Batman &amp; Robin
      </i>
      , meanwhile, was a critical and commercial failure. The
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      movie franchise was rebooted with director and co-writer
      <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nolan" title="Christopher Nolan">
       Christopher Nolan
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Begins" title="Batman Begins">
        Batman Begins
       </a>
      </i>
      in 2005,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_(film)" title="The Dark Knight (film)">
        The Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      in 2008 and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Rises" title="The Dark Knight Rises">
        The Dark Knight Rises
       </a>
      </i>
      in 2012. In 1989, the first issue of
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legends_of_the_Dark_Knight" title="Legends of the Dark Knight">
        Legends of the Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      , the first new solo Batman title in nearly 50 years, sold close to a million copies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-introduction_57-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-introduction-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The 1993 "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knightfall" title="Knightfall">
       Knightfall
      </a>
      " story arc introduced a new villain,
      <a href="/wiki/Bane_(comics)" title="Bane (comics)">
       Bane
      </a>
      , who critically injures Batman. Jean-Paul Valley, known as
      <a href="/wiki/Azrael_(comics)" title="Azrael (comics)">
       Azrael
      </a>
      , is called upon to wear the Batsuit during Bruce Wayne's convalescence. Writers
      <a href="/wiki/Doug_Moench" title="Doug Moench">
       Doug Moench
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Dixon" title="Chuck Dixon">
       Chuck Dixon
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Alan_Grant_(writer)" title="Alan Grant (writer)">
       Alan Grant
      </a>
      worked on the Batman titles during "Knightfall," and would also contribute to other Batman crossovers throughout the 1990s. 1998's "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Cataclysm" title="Batman: Cataclysm">
       Cataclysm
      </a>
      " storyline served as the precursor to 1999's "
      <a href="/wiki/No_Man%27s_Land_(comics)" title="No Man's Land (comics)">
       No Man's Land
      </a>
      ", a year-long storyline that ran through all the Batman-related titles dealing with the effects of an earthquake-ravaged Gotham City. At the conclusion of "No Man's Land", O'Neil stepped down as editor and was replaced by
      <a href="/wiki/Bob_Schreck" title="Bob Schreck">
       Bob Schreck
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Another writer who rose to prominence on the Batman comic series, was
      <a href="/wiki/Jeph_Loeb" title="Jeph Loeb">
       Jeph Loeb
      </a>
      . Along with longtime collaborator Tim Sale, they wrote two miniseries ("
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Long_Halloween" title="The Long Halloween">
       The Long Halloween
      </a>
      " and "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Dark_Victory" title="Batman: Dark Victory">
       Dark Victory
      </a>
      ") that pit an early in his career version of Batman against his entire rogue's gallery (most notably
      <a href="/wiki/Two-Face" title="Two-Face">
       Two-Face
      </a>
      , whose origin was re-envisioned by Loeb) while dealing with various mysteries involving
      <a href="/wiki/Serial_killer" title="Serial killer">
       serial killers
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Holiday_Killer" title="Holiday Killer">
       Holiday
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Hangman_(DC_Comics)" title="Hangman (DC Comics)">
       the Hangman
      </a>
      . In 2003, Loeb teamed with artist
      <a href="/wiki/Jim_Lee" title="Jim Lee">
       Jim Lee
      </a>
      to work on another mystery arc: "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Hush" title="Batman: Hush">
       Batman: Hush
      </a>
      " for the main Batman book. The twelve issue storyline saw Batman and Catwoman running the gauntlet against Batman's entire rogue's gallery, including an apparently resurrected
      <a href="/wiki/Jason_Todd" title="Jason Todd">
       Jason Todd
      </a>
      , while seeking to find the identity of the mysterious supervillain
      <a href="/wiki/Hush_(comics)" title="Hush (comics)">
       Hush
      </a>
      . While the character of Hush failed to catch on with readers, the arc was a sales success for DC. As the storyline was Jim Lee's first regular comic book work in nearly a decade, the series became #1 on the
      <a href="/wiki/Diamond_Comic_Distributors" title="Diamond Comic Distributors">
       Diamond Comic Distributors
      </a>
      sales chart for the first time since
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #500 (October 1993) and Jason Todd's appearance laid the groundwork for writer
      <a href="/wiki/Judd_Winick" title="Judd Winick">
       Judd Winick
      </a>
      's subsequent run as writer on
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      , with another multi-issue epic, "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Under_the_Hood" title="Batman: Under the Hood">
       Under the Hood
      </a>
      ," which ran from
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #637650.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2005, DC launched
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-Star_Batman_and_Robin" title="All-Star Batman and Robin">
        All-Star Batman and Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      , a stand-alone comic series set outside the existing DC Universe. Written by Frank Miller and drawn by Jim Lee, the series was a commercial success for DC Comics
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        58
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        59
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      though widely panned by critics for its writing and strong depictions of violence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        60
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        61
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Starting in 2006, the regular writers on
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      were
      <a href="/wiki/Grant_Morrison" title="Grant Morrison">
       Grant Morrison
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_Dini" title="Paul Dini">
       Paul Dini
      </a>
      , with Grant Morrison reincorporating controversial elements of Batman lore (most notably, the science fiction themed storylines of the 1950s Batman comics, which Morrison revised as hallucinations Batman suffered under the influence of various mind-bending gases and extensive sensory deprivation training) into the character. Morrison's run climaxed with "Batman R.I.P.", which brought Batman up against the villainous "Black Glove" organization, which sought to drive Batman into madness. "Batman R.I.P." segued into
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Final_Crisis" title="Final Crisis">
        Final Crisis
       </a>
      </i>
      (also written by Morrison), which saw the apparent death of Batman at the hands of
      <a href="/wiki/Darkseid" title="Darkseid">
       Darkseid
      </a>
      . In the 2009 miniseries
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Battle_for_the_Cowl" title="Batman: Battle for the Cowl">
        Batman: Battle for the Cowl
       </a>
      </i>
      , Wayne's former protg Dick Grayson becomes the new Batman, and Wayne's son Damian becomes the new Robin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-comics.ign.com_62-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-comics.ign.com-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Interview_63-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Interview-63">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        63
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In June 2009, Judd Winick returned to writing
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      , while Grant Morrison was given his own series, titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_and_Robin_(comic_book)" title="Batman and Robin (comic book)">
        Batman and Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-io9_64-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-io9-64">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        64
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2010, the storyline
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Return_of_Bruce_Wayne" title="Batman: The Return of Bruce Wayne">
        Batman: The Return of Bruce Wayne
       </a>
      </i>
      saw Bruce travel through history, eventually returning to the present day. Although he reclaimed the mantle of Batman, he also allowed Grayson to continue being Batman as well. Bruce decided to take his war on crime globally, which is the central focus of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Incorporated" title="Batman Incorporated">
        Batman Incorporated
       </a>
      </i>
      . DC Comics would later announce that Grayson would be the main character in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Batman and Robin
      </i>
      , while Wayne would be the main character in
      <i>
       Batman Incorporated
      </i>
      . Also, Bruce appeared in another ongoing series,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Dark_Knight" title="Batman: The Dark Knight">
        Batman: The Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="The_New_52">
       The New 52
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/The_New_52" title="The New 52">
       The New 52
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In September 2011, DC Comics' entire line of superhero books, including its
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      franchise, was canceled and relaunched with new #1 issues as part of
      <a href="/wiki/The_New_52" title="The New 52">
       The New 52
      </a>
      reboot. Bruce Wayne is the only character to be identified as Batman and will be featured in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Detective_Comics" title="Detective Comics">
        Detective Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_and_Robin_(comic_book)" title="Batman and Robin (comic book)">
        Batman and Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      , and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Dark_Knight" title="Batman: The Dark Knight">
        Batman: The Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      . Dick Grayson returns to the mantle of Nightwing and appears in his own ongoing series. While many characters have their histories significantly altered to attract newer, younger readers, Batman's history remains mostly intact.
      <i>
       Batman Incorporated
      </i>
      was relaunched in 2012 to complete the "Leviathan" storyline.
     </p>
     <p>
      Since the beginning of The New 52,
      <a href="/wiki/Scott_Snyder" title="Scott Snyder">
       Scott Snyder
      </a>
      has been the writer of the flagship Batman title. His first major story arc was "
      <a href="/wiki/Night_of_the_Owls" title="Night of the Owls">
       Night of the Owls
      </a>
      ", where Batman confronts the
      <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Owls" title="Court of Owls">
       Court of Owls
      </a>
      , a secret society that has controlled Gotham for centuries. The second story arc was "
      <a href="/wiki/Death_of_the_Family" title="Death of the Family">
       Death of the Family
      </a>
      ", where the Joker returns to Gotham and simultaneously attacks each member of the Batman family. The newest story arc is "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Zero_Year" title="Batman: Zero Year">
       Batman: Zero Year
      </a>
      ", which redefines Batman's origin in The New 52. It follows
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #0, published in June 2012, which explored the character's early years.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Fictional_character_biography">
       Fictional character biography
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Batman's history has undergone various revisions, both minor and major. Few elements of the character's history have remained constant. Scholars
      <a href="/wiki/William_Uricchio" title="William Uricchio">
       William Uricchio
      </a>
      and Roberta E. Pearson noted in the early 1990s, "Unlike some fictional characters, the Batman has no primary urtext set in a specific period, but has rather existed in a plethora of equally valid texts constantly appearing over more than five decades."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        65
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The central fixed event in the Batman stories is the character's
      <a href="/wiki/Origin_story" title="Origin story">
       origin story
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pearson_pg_186-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a little boy, Bruce Wayne is horrified and traumatized to see his parents, the physician Dr.
      <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Wayne" title="Thomas Wayne">
       Thomas Wayne
      </a>
      and his wife
      <a href="/wiki/Martha_Wayne" title="Martha Wayne">
       Martha
      </a>
      , being murdered by a mugger in front of his very eyes. This drives him to fight crime in
      <a href="/wiki/Gotham_City" title="Gotham City">
       Gotham City
      </a>
      as Batman. Pearson and Uricchio also noted beyond the origin story and such events as the introduction of Robin, "Until recently, the fixed and accruing and hence, canonized, events have been few in number,"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-pearson_pg_186-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      a situation altered by an increased effort by later Batman editors such as Dennis O'Neil to ensure consistency and continuity between stories.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_pg_191_67-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pearson_pg_191-67">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        67
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Golden_Age">
       Golden Age
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_(Earth-Two)" title="Batman (Earth-Two)">
       Batman (Earth-Two)
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      In Batman's first appearance in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #27, he is already operating as a crime-fighter.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        68
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Batman's origin is first presented in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #33 (November 1939) and is later expanded upon in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #47. As these comics state, Bruce Wayne is born to Dr. Thomas Wayne and his wife Martha, two very wealthy and charitable
      <a href="/wiki/Gotham_City" title="Gotham City">
       Gotham City
      </a>
      socialites. Bruce is brought up in
      <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Manor" title="Wayne Manor">
       Wayne Manor
      </a>
      , and leads a happy and privileged existence until the age of eight, when his parents are killed by a small-time criminal named
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Chill" title="Joe Chill">
       Joe Chill
      </a>
      while on their way home from a movie theater. That night, Bruce Wayne swears an oath to spend his life fighting crime. He engages in intense intellectual and physical training; however, he realizes that these skills alone would not be enough. "Criminals are a superstitious cowardly lot," Wayne remarks, "so my disguise must be able to strike terror into their hearts. I must be a creature of the night, black, terrible..." As if responding to his desires, a
      <a href="/wiki/Bat" title="Bat">
       bat
      </a>
      suddenly flies through the window, inspiring Bruce to take on the persona of Batman.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
       <a href="#cite_note-69">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        69
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In early strips, Batman's career as a vigilante earns him the ire of the police. During this period, Bruce Wayne has a fiance named
      <a href="/wiki/Julie_Madison" title="Julie Madison">
       Julie Madison
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
       <a href="#cite_note-70">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        70
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #1 takes in an orphaned circus acrobat,
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Grayson" title="Dick Grayson">
       Dick Grayson
      </a>
      , who becomes his sidekick,
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_(comics)" title="Robin (comics)">
       Robin
      </a>
      . Batman also becomes a founding member of the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_Society_of_America" title="Justice Society of America">
       Justice Society of America
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
       <a href="#cite_note-71">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        71
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      although he, like Superman, is an honorary member,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
       <a href="#cite_note-72">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        72
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and thus only participates occasionally. Batman's relationship with the law thaws quickly, and he is made an honorary member of
      <a href="/wiki/Gotham_City_Police_Department" title="Gotham City Police Department">
       Gotham City's police department
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        73
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      During this time,
      <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Pennyworth" title="Alfred Pennyworth">
       Alfred Pennyworth
      </a>
      arrives at Wayne Manor, and after deducing the Dynamic Duo's secret identities, joins their service as their butler.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        74
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Silver_Age">
       Silver Age
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Comic_Books" title="Silver Age of Comic Books">
       Silver Age of Comic Books
      </a>
      in DC Comics is sometimes held to have begun in 1956 when the publisher introduced
      <a href="/wiki/Flash_(Barry_Allen)" title="Flash (Barry Allen)">
       Barry Allen
      </a>
      as a new, updated version of
      <a href="/wiki/Flash_(comics)" title="Flash (comics)">
       The Flash
      </a>
      . Batman is not significantly changed by the late 1950s for the continuity which would be later referred to as
      <a href="/wiki/Earth-One" title="Earth-One">
       Earth-One
      </a>
      . The lighter tone Batman had taken in the period between the Golden and Silver Ages led to the stories of the late 1950s and early 1960s that often feature many science-fiction elements, and Batman is not significantly updated in the manner of other characters until
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #327 (May 1964), in which Batman reverts to his detective roots, with most science-fiction elements jettisoned from the series.
     </p>
     <p>
      After the introduction of DC Comics'
      <a href="/wiki/Multiverse_(DC_Comics)" title="Multiverse (DC Comics)">
       multiverse
      </a>
      in the 1960s, DC established that stories from the Golden Age star the
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_(Earth-Two)" title="Batman (Earth-Two)">
       Earth-Two Batman
      </a>
      , a character from a parallel world. This version of Batman partners with and marries the reformed Earth-Two Catwoman, Selina Kyle (as shown in
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Superman_Family" title="Superman Family">
        Superman Family
       </a>
      </i>
      #211) and fathers
      <a href="/wiki/Huntress_(Helena_Wayne)" title="Huntress (Helena Wayne)">
       Helena Wayne
      </a>
      , who, as the Huntress, becomes (along with Dick Grayson, the
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_(Earth-Two)" title="Robin (Earth-Two)">
       Earth-Two Robin
      </a>
      ) Gotham's protector once Wayne retires from the position to become police commissioner, a position he occupies until he is killed during one final adventure as Batman. Batman titles however often ignored that a distinction had been made between the pre-revamp and post-revamp Batmen (since unlike The Flash or
      <a href="/wiki/Green_Lantern" title="Green Lantern">
       Green Lantern
      </a>
      , Batman comics had been published without interruption through the 1950s) and would on occasionally make reference to stories from the Golden Age.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        75
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Nevertheless, details of Batman's history were altered or expanded upon through the decades. Additions include meetings with a future Superman during his youth, his upbringing by his uncle Philip Wayne (introduced in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #208, January/February 1969) after his parents' death, and appearances of his father and himself as prototypical versions of Batman and Robin, respectively.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
       <a href="#cite_note-76">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        76
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        77
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1980 then-editor
      <a href="/wiki/Paul_Levitz" title="Paul Levitz">
       Paul Levitz
      </a>
      commissioned the
      <i>
       Untold Legend of the Batman
      </i>
      <a href="/wiki/Limited_series" title="Limited series">
       limited series
      </a>
      to thoroughly chronicle Batman's origin and history.
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman meets and regularly works with other heroes during the Silver Age, most notably Superman, whom he began regularly working alongside in a series of team-ups in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/World%27s_Finest_Comics" title="World's Finest Comics">
        World's Finest Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      , starting in 1954 and continuing through the series' cancellation in 1986. Batman and Superman are usually depicted as close friends. As a founding member of the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_League" title="Justice League">
       Justice League of America
      </a>
      , Batman appears in its first story, in 1960's
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brave_and_the_Bold" title="Brave and the Bold">
        Brave and the Bold
       </a>
      </i>
      #28. In the 1970s and 1980s,
      <i>
       Brave and the Bold
      </i>
      became a Batman title, in which Batman teams up with a different
      <a href="/wiki/DC_Universe" title="DC Universe">
       DC Universe
      </a>
      superhero each month.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1969, Dick Grayson attends college as part of DC Comics' effort to revise the Batman comics. Additionally, Batman also moves from his mansion,
      <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Manor" title="Wayne Manor">
       Wayne Manor
      </a>
      into a
      <a href="/wiki/Penthouse_apartment" title="Penthouse apartment">
       penthouse apartment
      </a>
      atop the Wayne Foundation building in downtown Gotham City, in order to be closer to Gotham City's crime. Batman spends the 1970s and early 1980s mainly working solo, with occasional team-ups with Robin and/or Batgirl. Batman's adventures also become somewhat darker and more grim during this period, depicting increasingly violent crimes, including the first appearance (since the early Golden Age) of the Joker as a homicidal
      <a href="/wiki/Psychopathy" title="Psychopathy">
       psychopath
      </a>
      , and the arrival of
      <a href="/wiki/Ra%27s_al_Ghul" title="Ra's al Ghul">
       Ra's al Ghul
      </a>
      , a centuries-old terrorist who knows Batman's secret identity. In the 1980s, Dick Grayson becomes
      <a href="/wiki/Nightwing" title="Nightwing">
       Nightwing
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dc-ency_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-dc-ency-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the final issue of
      <i>
       Brave and the Bold
      </i>
      in 1983, Batman quits the Justice League and forms a new group called the
      <a href="/wiki/Outsiders_(comics)" title="Outsiders (comics)">
       Outsiders
      </a>
      . He serves as the team's leader until
      <i>
       Batman and the Outsiders
      </i>
      #32 (1986) and the comic subsequently changed its title.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_Batman">
       Modern Batman
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      After the 12-issue
      <a href="/wiki/Limited_series" title="Limited series">
       limited series
      </a>
      <i>
       Crisis on Infinite Earths
      </i>
      , DC Comics
      <a href="/wiki/Retroactive_continuity" title="Retroactive continuity">
       retconned
      </a>
      the histories of some major characters in an attempt at updating them for contemporary audiences. Frank Miller retold Batman's origin in the storyline "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Year_One" title="Batman: Year One">
       Year One
      </a>
      " from
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #404407, which emphasizes a grittier tone in the character.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        78
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Though the Earth-Two Batman is erased from history, many stories of Batman's Silver Age/Earth-One career (along with an amount of Golden Age ones) remain canonical in the post-Crisis universe, with his origins remaining the same in essence, despite alteration. For example, Gotham's police are mostly corrupt, setting up further need for Batman's existence. While Dick Grayson's past remains much the same, the history of
      <a href="/wiki/Jason_Todd" title="Jason Todd">
       Jason Todd
      </a>
      , the second Robin, is altered, turning the boy into the orphan son of a petty crook, who tries to steal the tires from the Batmobile.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        79
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also removed is the guardian Phillip Wayne leaving young Bruce to be raised by Alfred Pennyworth. Additionally, Batman is no longer a founding member of the Justice League of America, although he becomes leader for a short time of a new incarnation of the team launched in 1987. To help fill in the revised backstory for Batman following
      <i>
       Crisis
      </i>
      , DC launched a new Batman title called
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legends_of_the_Dark_Knight" title="Legends of the Dark Knight">
        Legends of the Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
