      in 1989 and has published various miniseries and one-shot stories since then that largely take place during the "Year One" period. Various stories from
      <a href="/wiki/Jeph_Loeb" title="Jeph Loeb">
       Jeph Loeb
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Matt_Wagner" title="Matt Wagner">
       Matt Wagner
      </a>
      also touch upon this era.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1988's "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_A_Death_in_the_Family" title="Batman: A Death in the Family">
       Batman: A Death in the Family
      </a>
      " storyline from
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #426429 Jason Todd, the second Robin, is killed by the Joker.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dc-ency_6-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-dc-ency-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Subsequently, Batman begins exhibiting an excessive, reckless approach to his crime-fighting, a result of the pain of losing Jason Todd. Batman works solo until the decade's close, when
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Drake" title="Tim Drake">
       Tim Drake
      </a>
      becomes the new Robin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        80
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2005, writers resurrected the Jason Todd character and have pitted him against his former mentor as the murderous vigilante the
      <a href="/wiki/Red_Hood" title="Red Hood">
       Red Hood
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Many of the major Batman storylines since the 1990s have been inter-title crossovers that run for a number of issues. In 1993, DC published both "
      <a href="/wiki/The_Death_of_Superman" title="The Death of Superman">
       The Death of Superman
      </a>
      " storyline and "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Knightfall" title="Knightfall">
       Knightfall
      </a>
      ". In that storyline's first phase, the new villain Bane paralyzes Batman, leading Wayne to ask
      <a href="/wiki/Azrael_(comics)" title="Azrael (comics)">
       Azrael
      </a>
      to take on the role. After the end of "Knightfall," the storylines split in two directions, following both the Azrael-Batman's adventures, and Bruce Wayne's quest to become Batman once more. The story arcs realign in "KnightsEnd," as Azrael becomes increasingly violent and is defeated by a healed Bruce Wayne. Wayne hands the Batman mantle to Dick Grayson (then Nightwing) for an interim period, while Wayne trains for a return to the role.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        81
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The 1994 company-wide crossover storyline "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zero_Hour_(comics)" title="Zero Hour (comics)">
       Zero Hour
      </a>
      " changes aspects of DC continuity again, including those of Batman. Noteworthy among these changes is that the general populace and the criminal element now considers Batman an urban legend rather than a known force. Similarly, the Waynes' killer is never caught or identified, effectively removing
      <a href="/wiki/Joe_Chill" title="Joe Chill">
       Joe Chill
      </a>
      from the new continuity, rendering stories such as "Year Two" non-canon.
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman once again becomes a member of the
      <a href="/wiki/Justice_League" title="Justice League">
       Justice League
      </a>
      during Grant Morrison's 1996 relaunch of the series, titled
      <i>
       JLA
      </i>
      . While Batman contributes greatly to many of the team's successes, the Justice League is largely uninvolved as Batman and Gotham City face catastrophe in the decade's closing crossover arc. In 1998's "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Cataclysm" title="Batman: Cataclysm">
       Cataclysm
      </a>
      " storyline, Gotham City is devastated by an earthquake and ultimately cut off from the United States. Deprived of many of his technological resources, Batman fights to reclaim the city from legions of gangs during 1999's "
      <a href="/wiki/No_Man%27s_Land_(comics)" title="No Man's Land (comics)">
       No Man's Land
      </a>
      ".
     </p>
     <p>
      Meanwhile, Batman's relationship with the Gotham City Police Department changed for the worse with the events of "Batman: Officer Down" and "Batman: War Games/War Crimes"; Batman's long-time law enforcement allies Commissioner Gordon and
      <a href="/wiki/Harvey_Bullock_(comics)" title="Harvey Bullock (comics)">
       Harvey Bullock
      </a>
      are forced out of the police department in "Officer Down", while "War Games" and "War Crimes" saw Batman become a wanted fugitive after a contingency plan of his to neutralize Gotham City's criminal underworld is accidentally triggered, resulting in a massive gang war that ends with the
      <a href="/wiki/Sadistic_personality_disorder" title="Sadistic personality disorder">
       sadistic
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Mask_(comics)" title="Black Mask (comics)">
       Black Mask
      </a>
      the undisputed ruler of the city's criminal gangs. Other troubles come for Batman in the form of
      <a href="/wiki/Lex_Luthor" title="Lex Luthor">
       Lex Luthor
      </a>
      (secretly behind the events of "No Man's Land"), who seeks revenge for Bruce Wayne cancelling all of his company's government contracts upon Luthor being elected President of the United States. Luthor arranges for the murder of Batman's on-again, off-again love interest Vesper (introduced in the mid-1990s) during the "Bruce Wayne: Murderer?" and "
      <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Wayne:_Fugitive" title="Bruce Wayne: Fugitive">
       Bruce Wayne: Fugitive
      </a>
      " story arcs. Though Batman is able to clear his name, he loses another ally in the form of his new bodyguard Sasha, who is recruited into the organization known as "Checkmate" while stuck in prison due to her refusal to turn state's evidence against her employer. While he was unable to prove that Luthor was behind the murder of Vesper, Batman does get his revenge with help from
      <a href="/wiki/Talia_al_Ghul" title="Talia al Ghul">
       Talia al Ghul
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Superman/Batman" title="Superman/Batman">
        Superman/Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      #16: not only does he bring down Lex Luthor's Presidency but also engages in a hostile take-over of Luthor's corporate holdings,
      <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy" title="Bankruptcy">
       bankrupting
      </a>
      the villain in the process.
     </p>
     <p>
      DC's 2005
      <a href="/wiki/Limited_series" title="Limited series">
       limited series
      </a>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Identity_Crisis_(DC_Comics)" title="Identity Crisis (DC Comics)">
        Identity Crisis
       </a>
      </i>
      reveals that JLA member
      <a href="/wiki/Zatanna" title="Zatanna">
       Zatanna
      </a>
      had edited Batman's memories to prevent him from stopping the League from
      <a href="/wiki/Lobotomy" title="Lobotomy">
       lobotomizing
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Light_(Arthur_Light)" title="Doctor Light (Arthur Light)">
       Dr. Light
      </a>
      after he raped
      <a href="/wiki/Sue_Dibny" title="Sue Dibny">
       Sue Dibny
      </a>
      . This served as a retcon for Batman's complete distrust for his fellow superheroes after he remembers, which, under writers such as Mark Waid in the "Tower of Babel" arc in JLA, manifested itself in the form of Batman keeping extensive files on how to kill his fellow superheroes. Batman later creates the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OMACs" title="OMACs">
       Brother I
      </a>
      satellite surveillance system to watch over and if necessary, kill the other heroes. It is eventually co-opted by
      <a href="/wiki/Maxwell_Lord" title="Maxwell Lord">
       Maxwell Lord
      </a>
      , who then kills superhero
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blue_Beetle_(Ted_Kord)" title="Blue Beetle (Ted Kord)">
       Blue Beetle
      </a>
      to keep him from alerting the Justice League of the existence of Batman's murderous creation. The revelation of Batman's creation and his tacit responsibility for Blue Beetle's death becomes a driving force in the lead-up to the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Infinite_Crisis" title="Infinite Crisis">
        Infinite Crisis
       </a>
      </i>
      miniseries, which again restructures DC continuity. In
      <i>
       Infinite Crisis
      </i>
      #7,
      <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Luthor,_Jr." title="Alexander Luthor, Jr.">
       Alexander Luthor, Jr.
      </a>
      mentions that in the newly rewritten history of the "
      <a href="/wiki/Multiverse_(DC_Comics)" title="Multiverse (DC Comics)">
       New Earth
      </a>
      ", created in the previous issue, the murderer of Martha and Thomas Wayne  again, Joe Chill  was captured, thus undoing the retcon created after
      <i>
       Zero Hour
      </i>
      . Batman and a team of superheroes destroy Brother Eye and the OMACs, though at the very end Batman reaches his apparent breaking point when Alexander Luthor Jr. seriously wounds Nightwing. Picking up a gun, Batman nearly shoots Luthor in order to avenge his former sidekick, until Wonder Woman convinces him to not pull the trigger.
     </p>
     <p>
      Following
      <i>
       Infinite Crisis
      </i>
      , Bruce Wayne, Dick Grayson (having recovered from his wounds), and Tim Drake retrace the steps Bruce had taken when he originally left Gotham City, to "rebuild Batman."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        82
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Face_the_Face" title="Batman: Face the Face">
        Face the Face
       </a>
      </i>
      storyline, Batman and Robin return to Gotham City after their year-long absence. Part of this absence is captured during Week 30 of the
      <i>
       52
      </i>
      series, which shows Batman fighting his inner demons.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        83
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Later on in
      <i>
       52
      </i>
      , Batman is shown undergoing an intense meditation ritual in
      <a href="/wiki/Nanda_Parbat" title="Nanda Parbat">
       Nanda Parbat
      </a>
      . This becomes an important part of the regular
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      title, which reveals that Batman is reborn as a more effective crime fighter while undergoing this ritual, having "hunted down and ate" the last traces of fear in his mind.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        84
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        85
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the end of the "Face the Face" story arc, Bruce officially adopts Tim (who had lost both of his parents at various points in the character's history) as his son.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        86
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The follow-up story arc in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_and_Son" title="Batman and Son">
        Batman and Son
       </a>
      </i>
      , introduces
      <a href="/wiki/Damian_Wayne" title="Damian Wayne">
       Damian Wayne
      </a>
      , who is Batman's son with
      <a href="/wiki/Talia_al_Ghul" title="Talia al Ghul">
       Talia al Ghul
      </a>
      . Batman, along with Superman and Wonder Woman, reforms the Justice League in the new
      <i>
       Justice League of America
      </i>
      series,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        87
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and is leading the newest incarnation of the
      <a href="/wiki/Outsiders_(comics)" title="Outsiders (comics)">
       Outsiders
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        88
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Grant_Morrison" title="Grant Morrison">
       Grant Morrison
      </a>
      's 2008 storyline, "
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_R.I.P." title="Batman R.I.P.">
       Batman R.I.P.
      </a>
      " featured Batman being physically and mentally broken by the enigmatic villain
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Glove" title="Black Glove">
       Black Glove
      </a>
      and attracted news coverage in advance of its highly promoted conclusion, which would speculated to feature the death of Bruce Wayne.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SUN_89-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SUN-89">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        89
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-INDY_90-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-INDY-90">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        90
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, though Batman is shown to possibly perish at the end of the arc, the two-issue arc "Last Rites," which leads into the crossover storylines "
      <a href="/wiki/Final_Crisis" title="Final Crisis">
       Final Crisis
      </a>
      ", shows that Batman survives his helicopter crash into the Gotham City River and returns to the Batcave, only to be summoned to the Hall of Justice by the JLA to help investigate the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Gods" title="New Gods">
       New God
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Orion_(comics)" title="Orion (comics)">
       Orion
      </a>
      's death. In the story, Batman is kidnapped by the New God
      <a href="/wiki/Granny_Goodness" title="Granny Goodness">
       Granny Goodness
      </a>
      and mentally probed by
      <a href="/wiki/Darkseid" title="Darkseid">
       Darkseid
      </a>
      's minions, as part of Darkseid's ultimately unsuccessful attempts to create clones of Bruce Wayne. The story ends with Batman retrieving the god-killing bullet used to kill Orion, setting up its use in "Final Crisis".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-deadatlast_91-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-deadatlast-91">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        91
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the pages of
      <i>
       Final Crisis
      </i>
      itself, the world is plunged into despair by the evil New God Darkseid. In
      <i>
       Final Crisis
      </i>
      #6 Batman confronts Darkseid and announces that he will make a once-in-a-lifetime exception by using a firearm when facing the villain. Batman shoots Darkseid with the god-killing bullet just as Darkseid unleashes his
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Omega_Sanction" title="Omega Sanction">
       Omega Sanction
      </a>
      upon Batman. Darkseid is killed and Batman is reduced to a charred skeleton.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        92
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       Final Crisis
      </i>
      #7 shows, however, that the Omega Sanction in fact sends its victim's consciousness into the distant past; Wayne is shown witnessing the passing of the first man,
      <a href="/wiki/Anthro_(comics)" title="Anthro (comics)">
       Anthro
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        93
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        94
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Wayne's "death" sets up the three-issue
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Battle_for_the_Cowl" title="Batman: Battle for the Cowl">
        Battle for the Cowl
       </a>
      </i>
      miniseries in which Wayne's ex-proteges compete for the "right" to assume the role of Batman, which concludes with Grayson becoming Batman,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
       <a href="#cite_note-95">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        95
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      while Tim Drake takes on the identity of
      <a href="/wiki/Red_Robin_(comics)" title="Red Robin (comics)">
       Red Robin
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        96
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Dick and Damian continue as Batman and Robin, and in the crossover storyline "
      <a href="/wiki/Blackest_Night" title="Blackest Night">
       Blackest Night
      </a>
      ", what appears to be Bruce's corpse is reanimated as a
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Lantern_Corps" title="Black Lantern Corps">
       Black Lantern
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Zombie" title="Zombie">
       zombie
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        97
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      but is later shown that Bruce's corpse is one of Darkseid's failed Batman clones. Dick and Batman's other friends conclude that Bruce is alive.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        98
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        99
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Bruce subsequently returns in Morrison's miniseries
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Return_of_Bruce_Wayne" title="Batman: The Return of Bruce Wayne">
        Batman: The Return of Bruce Wayne
       </a>
      </i>
      , which depicts his travels through time from
      <a href="/wiki/Prehistory" title="Prehistory">
       prehistory
      </a>
      to present-day Gotham.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAToday_100-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USAToday-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USAToday_100-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-USAToday-100">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        100
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Source_101-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Source-101">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        101
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SourceBatmanMay_102-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SourceBatmanMay-102">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        102
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Bruce's return sets up
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Incorporated" title="Batman Incorporated">
        Batman Incorporated
       </a>
      </i>
      , an ongoing series which focuses on Wayne franchising the Batman identity across the globe, allowing Dick and Damian to continue as Gotham's Dynamic Duo. Bruce publicly announces that Wayne Enterprises will aid Batman on his mission, known as "Batman, Incorporated." Due to rebooted continuity that occurred as part of DC's 2011 relaunch of all of its book,
      <a href="/wiki/The_New_52" title="The New 52">
       The New 52
      </a>
      , however, Grayson is restored as Nightwing with Wayne serving as the sole Batman once again. The relaunch also interrupts the publication of
      <i>
       Batman, Incorporated,
      </i>
      which resumes its story in 2012 with changes to suit the new status quo.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Personality">
       Personality
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Batman's primary character traits can be summarized as "wealth; physical prowess; deductive abilities and obsession."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-pearson_pg_186-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The details and tone of Batman comic books have varied over the years due to different creative teams. Dennis O'Neil noted that character consistency was not a major concern during early editorial regimes: "
      <a href="/wiki/Julius_Schwartz" title="Julius Schwartz">
       Julie Schwartz
      </a>
      did a Batman in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Detective
      </i>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Murray_Boltinoff" title="Murray Boltinoff">
       Murray Boltinoff
      </a>
      did a Batman in the
      <i>
       Brave and the Bold
      </i>
      and apart from the costume they bore very little resemblance to each other. Julie and Murray did not want to coordinate their efforts, nor were they asked to do so. Continuity was not important in those days."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
       <a href="#cite_note-103">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        103
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The driving force behind Batman's character is his parents' murder. Bob Kane and Bill Finger discussed Batman's background and decided that "there's nothing more traumatic than having your parents murdered before your eyes."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        104
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite his trauma, he sets his mind on studying to become a scientist
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_106-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and to train his body into physical perfection
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_105-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_106-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      to fight crime in
      <a href="/wiki/Gotham_City" title="Gotham City">
       Gotham City
      </a>
      as Batman, an inspired idea from Wayne's insight into the criminal mind.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_105-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-105">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        105
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_106-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-106">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        106
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Another of Batman's characterizations is a vigilante; in order to stop evil that started with the death of his parents, he must sometimes break laws himself. Although manifested differently by being re-told by different artists, it is nevertheless that the details and the prime components of Batman's origin have never varied at all in the comic books, the "reiteration of the basic origin events holds together otherwise divergent expressions".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        107
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The origin is the source of the character's traits and attributes, which play out in many of the character's adventures.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-pearson_pg_186-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman is often treated as a vigilante by other characters in his stories. Frank Miller views the character as "a
      <a href="/wiki/Dionysus" title="Dionysus">
       dionysian
      </a>
      figure, a force for
      <a href="/wiki/Anarchy" title="Anarchy">
       anarchy
      </a>
      that imposes an individual order."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        108
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Dressed as a bat, Batman deliberately cultivates a frightening persona in order to aid him in crime-fighting,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        109
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      a fear that originates from the criminals' own guilty
      <a href="/wiki/Conscience" title="Conscience">
       conscience
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        110
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Bruce_Wayne">
       Bruce Wayne
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The Batman is, in his everyday identity, Bruce Wayne, a wealthy businessman living in Gotham City. Wayne averts suspicion by acting the part of a superficial, dim-witted playboy idly living off his family's fortune (amassed through investment in real estate before the city became a bustling metropolis)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        111
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the profits of
      <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Enterprises" title="Wayne Enterprises">
       Wayne Enterprises
      </a>
      , his inherited conglomerate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        112
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He supports philanthropic causes through his nonprofit Wayne Foundation, but is more widely known as a celebrity socialite.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        113
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In public, he pretends to be a heavy drinker, using
      <a href="/wiki/Ginger_ale" title="Ginger ale">
       ginger ale
      </a>
      to suggest champagne and liberally serving alcohol to guests that he never actually consumes himself. In reality, he is a strict
      <a href="/wiki/Teetotalism" title="Teetotalism">
       teetotaler
      </a>
      concerned to maintain top physical fitness and mental acuity. In public, he appears frequently in the company of fashionable women to encourage
      <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">
       tabloid
      </a>
      gossip. In reality, there is less than meets the eye: though he leads an active romantic life, crime-fighting accounts for most of his night hours.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Inc0_114-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Inc0-114">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        114
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Bruce Wayne's calculated persona as a vapid, self-indulgent son of privilege finds literary precedent in Sir Percival Blakeney, hero of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Scarlet_Pimpernel" title="The Scarlet Pimpernel">
        The Scarlet Pimpernel
       </a>
      </i>
      stories by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baroness_Emmuska_Orczy" title="Baroness Emmuska Orczy">
       Baroness Emmuska Orczy
      </a>
      (1903), and Don Diego de la Vega, hero of the
      <a href="/wiki/Zorro" title="Zorro">
       Zorro
      </a>
      tales by
      <a href="/wiki/Johnston_McCulley" title="Johnston McCulley">
       Johnston McCulley
      </a>
      (1919). Like Bruce Wayne, Sir Percy and Don Diego are each members of gentry who invite contempt by publicly playing the fool. Also, like Bruce Wayne, each performs heroic deeds in secret and marks his work with a signature symbol.
     </p>
     <p>
      The name "Bruce Wayne" was chosen for certain connotations. According to co-creator Bill Finger, "Bruce Wayne's first name came from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robert_I_of_Scotland" title="Robert I of Scotland">
       Robert Bruce
      </a>
      , the Scottish patriot. Wayne, being a playboy, was a man of gentry. I searched for a name that would suggest colonialism. I tried Adams, Hancock...then I thought of
      <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Wayne" title="Anthony Wayne">
       Mad Anthony Wayne
      </a>
      ."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115">
       <a href="#cite_note-115">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        115
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Writers of Batman and Superman stories have often compared and contrasted the two. Interpretations vary depending on the writer, the story, and the timing. Grant Morrison
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        116
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      notes that both heroes "believe in the same kind of things" despite the day/night contrast their heroic roles display. He notes an equally stark contrast in their real identities. Bruce Wayne and Clark Kent belong to different social classes: "Bruce has a butler, Clark has a boss." T. James Musler's book
      <i>
       Unleashing the Superhero in Us All
      </i>
      explores the crucial role played by wealth in the Bruce Wayne story.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        117
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Modern stories tend to portray Bruce Wayne as the character's facade and the Batman as the truer representation of his personality
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118">
       <a href="#cite_note-118">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        118
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      (in counterpoint to the post-Crisis Superman, whose "
      <a href="/wiki/Clark_Kent" title="Clark Kent">
       Clark Kent
      </a>
      " persona is the 'real' personality, and "Superman" is the 'mask').
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        119
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        120
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In
      <i>
       Batman Unmasked
      </i>
      , a television documentary about the psychology of the character, Associate Professor of Social Psychology at the
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles" title="University of California, Los Angeles">
       University of California, Los Angeles
      </a>
      , and an adjunct
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Behavioral_science" title="Behavioral science">
       behavioral scientist
      </a>
      at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rand_Corporation" title="Rand Corporation">
       Rand Corporation
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Karney" title="Benjamin Karney">
       Benjamin Karney
      </a>
      , notes that the Batman's personality is driven by Bruce Wayne's inherent humanity; that "Batman, for all its benefits and for all of the time Bruce Wayne devotes to it, is ultimately a tool for Bruce Wayne's efforts to make the world better".
     </p>
     <p>
      Will Brooker notes in his book
      <i>
       Batman Unmasked
      </i>
      that "the confirmation of the Batman's identity lies with the young audience...he doesn't have to be Bruce Wayne; he just needs the suit and gadgets, the abilities, and most importantly the morality, the humanity. There's just a sense about him: 'they trust him... and they're never wrong."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121">
       <a href="#cite_note-121">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        121
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Bruce Wayne is a graduate of
      <a href="/wiki/Yale_Law_School" title="Yale Law School">
       Yale Law School
      </a>
      , as seen in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #439 (1974), in which the final page shows a Yale Law School diploma hanging in Bruce Wayne's office.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        122
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Dick_Grayson">
       Dick Grayson
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Grayson" title="Dick Grayson">
       Dick Grayson
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      On two occasions former Robin
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Grayson" title="Dick Grayson">
       Dick Grayson
      </a>
      has served as Batman. He served briefly while Wayne recovered from spinal injuries caused by
      <a href="/wiki/Bane_(comics)" title="Bane (comics)">
       Bane
      </a>
      in the 1993
      <i>
       Knightfall
      </i>
      storyline. He assumed the mantle again in a 2009 comic book while Wayne was believed dead, and served as a second Batman even after Wayne returned in 2010. As part of DC's
      <a href="/wiki/The_New_52" title="The New 52">
       2011 editorial mandate
      </a>
      , he returned to being Nightwing following the
      <i>
       Flashpoint
      </i>
      crossover event.
     </p>
     <p>
      In an interview with
      <a href="/wiki/IGN" title="IGN">
       IGN
      </a>
      , Morrison details that having Dick Grayson as Batman and
      <a href="/wiki/Damian_Wayne" title="Damian Wayne">
       Damian Wayne
      </a>
      as Robin represented a "reverse" of the normal dynamic between Batman and Robin, with, "a more light-hearted and spontaneous Batman and a scowling, badass Robin." Morrison explains his intentions for the new characterization of Batman: "Dick Grayson is kind of this consummate superhero. The guy has been Batman's partner since he was a kid, he's led the
      <a href="/wiki/Teen_Titans" title="Teen Titans">
       Teen Titans
      </a>
      , and he's trained with everybody in the DC Universe. So he's a very different kind of Batman. He's a lot easier; He's a lot looser and more relaxed."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-comics.ign.com_62-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-comics.ign.com-62">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        62
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Characterization">
       Characterization
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Skills_and_abilities">
       Skills and abilities
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Batman has no inherent superhuman powers. To compensate for this, he relies on "his own scientific knowledge, detective skills, and athletic prowess."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_p17_30-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wright_p17-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the stories, Batman is regarded as one of the world's greatest detectives, if not the world's greatest crime solver.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
       <a href="#cite_note-123">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        123
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In Grant Morrison's first storyline in
      <i>
       JLA
      </i>
      , Superman describes Batman as "the most dangerous man on Earth," able to defeat a team of superpowered aliens by himself in order to rescue his imprisoned teammates. He has spent a significant portion of his life traveling the world and acquiring the skills needed to aid in his crusade against crime. His knowledge and expertise in almost every discipline known to man is nearly unparalleled by any other character in the DC Universe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        124
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Superman considers Batman to be one of the most brilliant minds on the planet when Batman and other genius-level intellects (
      <a href="/wiki/Lex_Luthor" title="Lex Luthor">
       Lex Luthor
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Atom_(Ray_Palmer)" title="Atom (Ray Palmer)">
       Ray Palmer
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Shay_Veritas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Shay Veritas (page does not exist)">
       Shay Veritas
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Cyborg_(comics)" title="Cyborg (comics)">
       Cyborg
      </a>
      ) try to save Superman from an infection in the
      <a href="/wiki/Superman:_Doomed" title="Superman: Doomed">
       Superman: Doomed
      </a>
      story arc.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        125
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman is an expert in
      <a href="/wiki/Interrogation" title="Interrogation">
       interrogation
      </a>
      techniques and would often use
      <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement" title="Law enforcement">
       law enforcement
      </a>
      methods, as well as
      <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">
       torture
      </a>
      . Several of his methods include hanging a person over the edge of a building by the leg or chaining a person upside down and
      <a href="/wiki/Strike_(attack)" title="Strike (attack)">
       beating
      </a>
      them. He usually just uses his
      <a href="/wiki/Intimidation" title="Intimidation">
       frightening
      </a>
      appearance to get answers. Batman has been repeatedly described as one of the greatest martial artists in the DC Universe; his skills in martial arts are said to rival such notable martial artists as
      <a href="/wiki/Lady_Shiva" title="Lady Shiva">
       Lady Shiva
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Tiger" title="Bronze Tiger">
       Bronze Tiger
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Richard_Dragon" title="Richard Dragon">
       Richard Dragon
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman has the ability to function while
      <a href="/wiki/Physical_strength" title="Physical strength">
       tolerating massive amounts of physical pain
      </a>
      , and to withstand
      <a href="/wiki/Telepathy" title="Telepathy">
       telepathy
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mind_control" title="Mind control">
       mind control
      </a>
      . He is a master of
      <a href="/wiki/Disguise" title="Disguise">
       disguise
      </a>
      , often gathering information under the identity of Matches Malone, a notorious gangster. He is also skilled in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spying" title="Spying">
       spying
      </a>
      , thus allowing him to hide in unexpected places. His
      <a href="/wiki/Ninjutsu" title="Ninjutsu">
       ninjutsu
      </a>
      training has made him a master at stealth where he can appear and disappear in rather impossible situations. He is efficient with observation skills,
      <a href="/wiki/Logical_reasoning" title="Logical reasoning">
       logical reasoning
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Forensic_investigation" title="Forensic investigation">
       forensic investigation
      </a>
      . He is also efficient in
      <a href="/wiki/Escapology" title="Escapology">
       escapology
      </a>
      , thus allowing him to break free of nearly inescapable
      <a href="/wiki/Deathtrap_(plot_device)" title="Deathtrap (plot device)">
       deathtraps
      </a>
      with very little to no harm.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Costume">
       Costume
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Batsuit" title="Batsuit">
       Batsuit
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Batman's costume incorporates the imagery of a bat in order to frighten criminals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A1_126-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-A1-126">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        126
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The details of the Batman costume change repeatedly through various stories and media, but the most distinctive elements remain consistent: a scallop-hem cape, a cowl covering most of the face featuring a pair of batlike ears, and a stylized bat emblem on the chest, and the ever-present utility belt. The costumes' colors are traditionally blue and grey,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A1_126-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-A1-126">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        126
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      although this colorization arose due to the way comic book art is colored.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A1_126-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-A1-126">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        126
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      His
      <a href="/wiki/Batsuit" title="Batsuit">
       batsuit
      </a>
      aids in his combat against enemies, having the properties of both
      <a href="/wiki/Kevlar" title="Kevlar">
       Kevlar
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Nomex" title="Nomex">
       Nomex
      </a>
      . It protects him from gunfire and other significant impacts. However, Batman's most defining characteristic is his strong commitment to justice and his unwillingness to take life, regardless of the situation he has faced. This unyielding moral rectitude has earned him the respect of several heroes in the DC Universe, most notably that of
      <a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">
       Superman
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Wonder_Woman" title="Wonder Woman">
       Wonder Woman
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Finger and Kane conceptualized Batman as having a black cape and cowl and grey suit, but conventions in coloring called for black to be highlighted with blue.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A1_126-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-A1-126">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        126
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      This coloring has been claimed by Larry Ford, in
      <i>
       Place, Power, Situation, and Spectacle: A Geography of Film
      </i>
      , to be an inversion of conventional color-coding symbolism, which sees "bad guys" wearing dark colors.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
       <a href="#cite_note-127">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        127
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman's gloves typically feature three scallops that protrude from long, gauntlet-like cuffs, although in his earliest appearances he wore short, plain gloves without the scallops. A yellow ellipse around the bat logo on the character's chest was added in 1964, and became the hero's trademark symbol, akin to the red and yellow "S" symbol of Superman.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
       <a href="#cite_note-128">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        128
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The overall look of the character, particularly the length of the cowl's ears and of the cape, varies greatly depending on the artist. Dennis O'Neil said, "We now say that Batman has two hundred suits hanging in the Batcave so they don't have to look the same . . . Everybody loves to draw Batman, and everybody wants to put their own spin on it."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
       <a href="#cite_note-129">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        129
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Equipment">
       Equipment
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote boilerplate seealso">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Batman%27s_utility_belt" title="Batman's utility belt">
       Batman's utility belt
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:USD205998.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="340" data-file-width="469" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USD205998.png/220px-USD205998.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USD205998.png/330px-USD205998.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USD205998.png/440px-USD205998.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:USD205998.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The 1966 television Batmobile, built by
        <a href="/wiki/George_Barris_(auto_customizer)" title="George Barris (auto customizer)">
         George Barris
        </a>
        from a
        <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Futura" title="Lincoln Futura">
         Lincoln Futura
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Concept_car" title="Concept car">
         concept car
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1495" data-file-width="2436" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg/220px-Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg/330px-Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg/440px-Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batmobile-to-Wiki-by-Zachi-Evenor.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Batmobile from
        <a href="/wiki/Tim_Burton" title="Tim Burton">
         Tim Burton
        </a>
        's 1989
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Batman_(1989)" title="Batman (1989)">
          Batman
         </a>
        </i>
        film.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Batman uses a large arsenal of specialized gadgets in his war against crime, the designs of which usually share a bat motif. Batman historian
      <a href="/wiki/Les_Daniels" title="Les Daniels">
       Les Daniels
      </a>
      credits
      <a href="/wiki/Gardner_Fox" title="Gardner Fox">
       Gardner Fox
      </a>
      with creating the concept of Batman's arsenal with the introduction of the utility belt in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #29 (July 1939) and the first bat-themed weapons the
      <a href="/wiki/Batarang" title="Batarang">
       batarang
      </a>
      and the "Batgyro" in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #31 and #32 (September; October 1939).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vapzdg_26-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-vapzdg-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Batman's primary vehicle is the
      <a href="/wiki/Batmobile" title="Batmobile">
       Batmobile
      </a>
      , which is usually depicted as an imposing black car with large
      <a href="/wiki/Car_tailfin" title="Car tailfin">
       tailfins
      </a>
      that suggest a bat's wings. Batman's other vehicles include the
      <a href="/wiki/Batplane" title="Batplane">
       Batplane
      </a>
      (aka the Batwing),
      <a href="/wiki/Batboat" title="Batboat">
       Batboat
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bat-Sub" title="Bat-Sub">
       Bat-Sub
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Batcycle" title="Batcycle">
       Batcycle
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In proper practice, the "bat" prefix (as in batmobile or batarang) is rarely used by Batman himself when referring to his equipment, particularly after some portrayals (primarily the 1960s
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)" title="Batman (TV series)">
       <i>
        Batman
       </i>
       live-action television show
      </a>
      and the
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Super_Friends" title="Super Friends">
        Super Friends
       </a>
      </i>
      animated series) stretched the practice to
      <a href="/wiki/Camp_(style)" title="Camp (style)">
       campy
      </a>
      proportions. The 1960s television series Batman has an arsenal that includes such "bat-" names as the bat-computer, bat-scanner, bat-radar, bat-cuffs, bat-pontoons, bat-drinking water dispenser, bat-camera with polarized bat-filter, bat-
      <a href="/wiki/Shark_repellent" title="Shark repellent">
       shark repellent
      </a>
      bat-spray, and bat-rope. The storyline "A Death in the Family" suggests that given Batman's grim nature, he is unlikely to have adopted the "bat" prefix on his own.
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman keeps most of his field equipment in a utility belt. Over the years it is shown to contain a virtually limitless variety of crime-fighting tools. Different versions of the belt have these items stored in either pouches or hard cylinders attached evenly around it. A typical major exception to the range of Batman's equipment are conventional
      <a href="/wiki/Firearm" title="Firearm">
       firearms
      </a>
      , which he refuses to use on principle considering that weapon class was the instrument of his parents' murder. Modern depictions of Batman have him compromise for practicality by arming his vehicles mainly for the purpose of removing obstacles or disabling enemy vehicles.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Bat-Signal">
       Bat-Signal
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Bat-Signal" title="Bat-Signal">
       Bat-Signal
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      When Batman is needed, the Gotham City police activate a
      <a href="/wiki/Searchlight" title="Searchlight">
       searchlight
      </a>
      with a bat-shaped insignia over the lens called the Bat-Signal, which shines into the night sky, creating a bat-symbol on a passing cloud which can be seen from any point in Gotham. The origin of the signal varies, depending on the continuity and medium.
     </p>
     <p>
      In various incarnations, most notably the 1960s
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)" title="Batman (TV series)">
       <i>
        Batman
       </i>
       TV series
      </a>
      , Commissioner Gordon also has a dedicated phone line, dubbed the Bat-Phone, connected to a bright red telephone (in the TV series) which sits on a wooden base and has a transparent cake cover on top. The line connects directly to Batman's residence,
      <a href="/wiki/Wayne_Manor" title="Wayne Manor">
       Wayne Manor
      </a>
      , specifically both to a similar phone sitting on the desk in Bruce Wayne's study and the extension phone in the Batcave.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Batcave">
       Batcave
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Batcave" title="Batcave">
       Batcave
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Batcave is Batman's secret headquarters, consisting of a series of subterranean caves beneath his mansion, Wayne Manor. It serves as his command center for both local and global surveillance, as well as housing his vehicles and equipment for his war on crime. It also is a storeroom for Batman's memorabilia. In both the comic
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Shadow_of_the_Bat" title="Batman: Shadow of the Bat">
        Batman: Shadow of the Bat
       </a>
      </i>
      (issue #45) and the 2005 film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Begins" title="Batman Begins">
        Batman Begins
       </a>
      </i>
      , the cave is said to have been part of the
      <a href="/wiki/Underground_Railroad" title="Underground Railroad">
       Underground Railroad
      </a>
      . Of the heroes and villains who see the Batcave, few know where it is located.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Supporting_characters">
       Supporting characters
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BatmanRobin.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="275" data-file-width="300" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/67/BatmanRobin.jpg/220px-BatmanRobin.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/67/BatmanRobin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/67/BatmanRobin.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BatmanRobin.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Batman with his
        <a href="/wiki/Sidekick" title="Sidekick">
         sidekick
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Robin_(comics)" title="Robin (comics)">
         Robin
        </a>
        , painting by
        <a href="/wiki/Alex_Ross" title="Alex Ross">
         Alex Ross
        </a>
        , based on the cover of
        <i>
         Batman
        </i>
        #9 by
        <a href="/wiki/Jack_Burnley" title="Jack Burnley">
         Jack Burnley
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Batman_supporting_characters" title="List of Batman supporting characters">
       List of Batman supporting characters
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Batman's interactions with both villains and cohorts have, over time, developed a strong supporting cast of characters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-pearson_pg_186-66">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        66
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_police" title="Chief of police">
       Commissioner
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/James_Gordon_(comics)" title="James Gordon (comics)">
       James "Jim" Gordon
      </a>
      , Batman's ally in the Gotham City police, debuted along with Batman in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #27. Gordon has been a consistent presence ever since. As a crime-fighting
      <a href="/wiki/Everyman" title="Everyman">
       everyman
      </a>
      , he shares the Batman's goals while offering, much as the character of Watson does in
      <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">
       Sherlock Holmes
      </a>
      stories, a normal person's perspective on the work of an extraordinary genius. Later the Batman gained a butler. Alfred Pennyworth serves as Bruce Wayne's loyal father figure and is one of the few persons to know his secret identity. The character "[lends] a homey touch to Batman's environs and [is] ever ready to provide a steadying and reassuring hand" to the hero and his sidekick.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boichel_p8_130-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Boichel_p8-130">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        130
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 1970s,
      <a href="/wiki/Lucius_Fox" title="Lucius Fox">
       Lucius Fox
      </a>
      appeared as Bruce Wayne's business manager and technology specialist.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Robin">
       Robin
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      <span id="Robin">
      </span>
     </p>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_(comics)" title="Robin (comics)">
       Robin (comics)
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      A widely recognized supporting character for many years has been the young sidekick Robin.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        131
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Bill Finger stated that he wanted to include Robin because "Batman didn't have anyone to talk to, and it got a little tiresome always having him thinking."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
       <a href="#cite_note-132">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        132
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first Robin, Dick Grayson, was introduced in 1940. In the 1970s he finally grew up, went off to college and became the hero
      <a href="/wiki/Nightwing" title="Nightwing">
       Nightwing
      </a>
      . A second Robin,
      <a href="/wiki/Jason_Todd" title="Jason Todd">
       Jason Todd
      </a>
      , appeared in the 1980s. In the stories he was eventually badly beaten and then killed in an explosion set by the Joker, but later revived as an adversary using the Joker's old persona, the
      <a href="/wiki/Red_Hood" title="Red Hood">
       Red Hood
      </a>
      .
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carrie_Kelly" title="Carrie Kelly">
       Carrie Kelly
      </a>
      , the first female Robin to appear in Batman stories, was the final Robin in the continuity of Frank Miller's graphic novels
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Returns" title="The Dark Knight Returns">
        The Dark Knight Returns
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Strikes_Again" title="The Dark Knight Strikes Again">
        The Dark Knight Strikes Again
       </a>
      </i>
      , fighting alongside an aging Batman in stories set out of the mainstream continuity. The third Robin in mainstream comics is
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Drake" title="Tim Drake">
       Tim Drake
      </a>
      , who first appeared in 1989. He went on to star in his own comic series. In the first decade of the new millennium,
      <a href="/wiki/Stephanie_Brown_(comics)" title="Stephanie Brown (comics)">
       Stephanie Brown
      </a>
      served as the fourth in-universe Robin between the character's stints as
      <a href="/wiki/Stephanie_Brown_(comics)" title="Stephanie Brown (comics)">
       The Spoiler
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Batgirl" title="Batgirl">
       Batgirl
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        133
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      After Stephanie Brown's apparent death, Drake resumed the role of Robin for a time. The role eventually passed to
      <a href="/wiki/Damian_Wayne" title="Damian Wayne">
       Damian Wayne
      </a>
      , the ten-year-old son of Bruce Wayne and
      <a href="/wiki/Talia_al_Ghul" title="Talia al Ghul">
       Talia al Ghul
      </a>
      , in the late 2000s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        134
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Damian's tenure as
      <i>
       du jour
      </i>
      Robin ended when the character was killed off in the pages of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Incorporated" title="Batman Incorporated">
        Batman Incorporated
       </a>
      </i>
      in 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
       <a href="#cite_note-135">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        135
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Batman's next young sidekick is Harper Row, a young woman who avoids the name Robin, debuting under the codename
      <a href="/wiki/Bluebird_(DC_Comics)" title="Bluebird (DC Comics)">
       Bluebird
      </a>
      in 2014. Unlike the Robins, Bluebird is willing and permitted to use
      <a href="/wiki/Firearm" title="Firearm">
       firearms
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        136
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Enemies">
       Enemies
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_Batman_Family_adversaries" title="List of Batman Family adversaries">
       List of Batman Family adversaries
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batmanfoes.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="448" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/da/Batmanfoes.jpg/220px-Batmanfoes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/da/Batmanfoes.jpg/330px-Batmanfoes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/da/Batmanfoes.jpg/440px-Batmanfoes.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batmanfoes.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A gathering of Batman's villains; art by
        <a href="/wiki/Jim_Lee" title="Jim Lee">
         Jim Lee
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Batman faces a variety of foes ranging from common criminals to outlandish supervillains. Many of them mirror aspects of the Batman's character and development, often having tragic origin stories that lead them to a life of crime.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boichel_p8_130-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Boichel_p8-130">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        130
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Batman's "most implacable foe" is the
      <a href="/wiki/Joker_(comics)" title="Joker (comics)">
       Joker
      </a>
      , a homicidal maniac with a clown-like appearance who, as a "personification of the irrational", represents "everything Batman [opposes]."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boichel_p9_34-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Boichel_p9-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other long time recurring foes include
      <a href="/wiki/Catwoman" title="Catwoman">
       Catwoman
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Bane_(comics)" title="Bane (comics)">
       Bane
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Scarecrow_(DC_Comics)" title="Scarecrow (DC Comics)">
       Scarecrow
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Penguin_(comics)" title="Penguin (comics)">
       Penguin
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Two-Face" title="Two-Face">
       Two-Face
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Riddler" title="Riddler">
       Riddler
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mr._Freeze" title="Mr. Freeze">
       Mr. Freeze
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Poison_Ivy_(comics)" title="Poison Ivy (comics)">
       Poison Ivy
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Ra%27s_al_Ghul" title="Ra's al Ghul">
       Ra's al Ghul
      </a>
      , among many others.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Others">
       Others
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The Batman is at times a member of superhero teams such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Justice_League_of_America" title="Justice League of America">
       Justice League of America
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Outsiders_(comics)" title="Outsiders (comics)">
       Outsiders
      </a>
      . Batman has often been paired in adventure with his Justice League teammate Superman, notably as the co-stars of
      <i>
       World's Finest
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Superman/Batman" title="Superman/Batman">
        Superman/Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      series. In pre-Crisis continuity, the two are depicted as close friends; however, in current continuity, they have a mutually respectful but uneasy relationship, with an emphasis on their differing views on crime-fighting and justice. In
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Superman/Batman" title="Superman/Batman">
        Superman/Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      #3 (December 2003),
      <a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">
       Superman
      </a>
      observes, "Sometimes, I admit, I think of Bruce as a man in a costume. Then, with some gadget from his utility belt, he reminds me that he has an extraordinarily inventive mind. And how lucky I am to be able to call on him."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        137
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Bruce Wayne has been portrayed as involved romantically with many women through his various incarnations. Some have been respected society figures:
      <a href="/wiki/Julie_Madison" title="Julie Madison">
       Julie Madison
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Vicki_Vale" title="Vicki Vale">
       Vicki Vale
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Silver_St._Cloud" title="Silver St. Cloud">
       Silver St. Cloud
      </a>
      . Some have been allies:
      <a href="/wiki/Wonder_Woman" title="Wonder Woman">
       Wonder Woman
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sasha_Bordeaux" title="Sasha Bordeaux">
       Sasha Bordeaux
      </a>
      . Some have been villainesses: the
      <a href="/wiki/Catwoman" title="Catwoman">
       Catwoman
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Talia_al_Ghul" title="Talia al Ghul">
       Talia al Ghul
      </a>
      . With the latter he sired a son, Damian, and with the former of whom sired a daughter, Helena (on Earth-Two). While these relationships tend to be short, Batman's attraction to the Catwoman is present in nearly every version and medium in which the characters appear. Writers have varied in the approach over the years to the 'playboy' aspect of Bruce Wayne's persona; some show his playboy reputation as a manufactured illusion to support his mission as Batman, while others have depicted Bruce Wayne as genuinely enjoying the benefits of being "Gotham's most eligible bachelor."
     </p>
     <p>
      Other supporting characters in the Batman's world include
      <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Gordon" title="Barbara Gordon">
       Barbara Gordon
      </a>
      , Commissioner Gordon's daughter, who has fought crime under the aliases
      <a href="/wiki/Batgirl" title="Batgirl">
       Batgirl
      </a>
      and, during a period in which she was confined to a wheelchair due to a gunshot wound inflicted by the Joker, the
      <a href="/wiki/Hacker_(computer_security)" title="Hacker (computer security)">
       computer hacker
      </a>
      Oracle; Azrael, a would-be assassin who replaces Bruce Wayne as Batman for a time;
      <a href="/wiki/Cassandra_Cain" title="Cassandra Cain">
       Cassandra Cain
      </a>
      , an assassin's daughter who became the new Batgirl;
      <a href="/wiki/Huntress_(comics)" title="Huntress (comics)">
       Huntress
      </a>
      , the sole surviving member of a mob family turned Gotham vigilante who has worked with Batman on occasion,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spoiler_(comics)" title="Spoiler (comics)">
       Stephanie Brown
      </a>
      , the daughter of a criminal who operated as the Spoiler and temporarily as Robin, Ace the Bat-Hound, Batman's canine partner;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138D_138-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-138D-138">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        138
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and Bat-Mite, an extra-dimensional imp who idolizes Batman.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138D_138-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-138D-138">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        138
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cultural_impact">
       Cultural impact
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Batman has become a pop culture icon, recognized around the world. The character's presence has extended beyond his comic book origins; events such as the release of the 1989
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      film and its accompanying merchandising "brought the Batman to the forefront of public consciousness."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-introduction_57-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-introduction-57">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        57
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In an article commemorating the sixtieth anniversary of the character,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">
        The Guardian
       </a>
      </i>
      wrote, "Batman is a figure blurred by the endless reinvention that is modern mass culture. He is at once an icon and a commodity: the perfect cultural artefact for the 21st century."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
       <a href="#cite_note-139">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        139
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In addition, media outlets have often used the character in trivial and comprehensive surveys 
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">
        Forbes
       </a>
      </i>
      magazine estimated Bruce Wayne to be the 8th-richest fictional character with his $6.9billion fortune, several places after
      <a href="/wiki/Iron_Man" title="Iron Man">
       Iron Man
      </a>
      , who is at 5.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes_140-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-forbes-140">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        140
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BusinessWeek" title="BusinessWeek">
        BusinessWeek
       </a>
      </i>
      listed the character as one of the ten most intelligent superheroes appearing in American comics.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        141
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" title="Entertainment Weekly">
        Entertainment Weekly
       </a>
      </i>
      named Batman as one of
      <i>
       The 20 All Time Coolest Heroes in Pop Culture
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142">
       <a href="#cite_note-142">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        142
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He also was placed on
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years%E2%80%A6100_Heroes_and_Villains" title="AFI's 100 Years100 Heroes and Villains">
        AFI's 100 Years100 Heroes and Villains
       </a>
      </i>
      from the
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_(1989_film)" title="Batman (1989 film)">
       1989 feature film
      </a>
      by the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">
       American Film Institute
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        143
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The character was the focus of the 2008 non-fiction book
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Becoming_Batman:_The_Possibility_of_a_Superhero" title="Becoming Batman: The Possibility of a Superhero">
        Becoming Batman: The Possibility of a Superhero
       </a>
      </i>
      by
      <a href="/wiki/E._Paul_Zehr" title="E. Paul Zehr">
       E. Paul Zehr
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="In_other_media">
       In other media
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_franchise_media" title="Batman franchise media">
       Batman franchise media
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The character of Batman has appeared in various media aside from comic books. The character has been developed as a vehicle for newspaper syndicated
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">
       comic strips
      </a>
      , books, radio dramas, television, a
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_Live" title="Batman Live">
       stage show
      </a>
      , and several theatrical feature films. The first adaptation of Batman was as a daily newspaper
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">
       comic strip
      </a>
      which premiered on October 25, 1943.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        144
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      That same year the character was adapted in the 15-part
      <a href="/wiki/Serial_film" title="Serial film">
       serial
      </a>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(serial)" title="Batman (serial)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      , with
      <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Wilson" title="Lewis Wilson">
       Lewis Wilson
      </a>
      becoming the first actor to portray Batman on screen. While Batman never had a radio series of his own, the character made occasional guest appearance in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Superman_(radio)" title="The Adventures of Superman (radio)">
        The Adventures of Superman
       </a>
      </i>
      starting in 1945 on occasions when Superman voice actor
      <a href="/wiki/Bud_Collyer" title="Bud Collyer">
       Bud Collyer
      </a>
      needed time off.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dan99p64_145-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dan99p64-145">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        145
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A second movie serial,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_and_Robin_(serial)" title="Batman and Robin (serial)">
        Batman and Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      , followed in 1949, with
      <a href="/wiki/Robert_Lowery_(actor)" title="Robert Lowery (actor)">
       Robert Lowery
      </a>
      taking over the role of Batman. The exposure provided by these adaptations during the 1940s "helped make [Batman] a household name for millions who never bought a comic book."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dan99p64_145-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dan99p64-145">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        145
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the 1964 publication of
      <a href="/wiki/Donald_Barthelme" title="Donald Barthelme">
       Donald Barthelme
      </a>
      's collection of short stories "Come Back, Dr. Caligari", Barthelme wrote "The Joker's Greatest Triumph." Batman is portrayed for purposes of spoof as a pretentious French-speaking rich man.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        146
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batman_Kane.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="250" data-file-width="298" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/00/Batman_Kane.jpg/220px-Batman_Kane.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/00/Batman_Kane.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/00/Batman_Kane.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batman_Kane.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Michael_Keaton" title="Michael Keaton">
         Michael Keaton
        </a>
        as Batman, with
        <a href="/wiki/Bob_Kane" title="Bob Kane">
         Bob Kane
        </a>
