        on the set of
        <a href="/wiki/Tim_Burton" title="Tim Burton">
         Tim Burton
        </a>
        's
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Batman_(1989_film)" title="Batman (1989 film)">
          Batman
         </a>
        </i>
        (1989)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)" title="Batman (TV series)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      television series, starring
      <a href="/wiki/Adam_West" title="Adam West">
       Adam West
      </a>
      , premiered in January 1966 on the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">
       ABC
      </a>
      television network. Inflected with a
      <a href="/wiki/Camp_(style)" title="Camp (style)">
       camp
      </a>
      sense of humor, the show became a pop culture phenomenon. In his memoir,
      <i>
       Back to the Batcave
      </i>
      , West notes his dislike for the term 'camp' as it was applied to the 1960s series, opining that the show was instead a
      <a href="/wiki/Farce" title="Farce">
       farce
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Parody" title="Parody">
       lampoon
      </a>
      , and a deliberate one, at that. The series ran for 120 episodes, ending in 1968. In between the first and second season of the
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      television series the cast and crew made the theatrical film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(1966_film)" title="Batman (1966 film)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      (1966).
      <a href="/wiki/The_Kinks" title="The Kinks">
       The Kinks
      </a>
      performed the theme song from the Batman series on their 1967 album
      <a href="/wiki/Live_at_Kelvin_Hall" title="Live at Kelvin Hall">
       Live at Kelvin Hall
      </a>
      . The popularity of the
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      TV series also resulted in the first animated adaptation of Batman in the series
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Batman/Superman_Hour" title="The Batman/Superman Hour">
        The Batman/Superman Hour
       </a>
      </i>
      ;
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
       <a href="#cite_note-147">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        147
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      the Batman segments of the series were repackaged as
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Adventures_of_Batman" title="The Adventures of Batman">
        The Adventures of Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Batman with Robin the Boy Wonder
      </i>
      which produced thirty-three episodes between 1968 and 1977. From 1973 until 1986, Batman had a starring role in ABC's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Super_Friends" title="Super Friends">
        Super Friends
       </a>
      </i>
      series, which was animated by
      <a href="/wiki/Hanna-Barbera" title="Hanna-Barbera">
       Hanna-Barbera
      </a>
      .
      <a href="/wiki/Olan_Soule" title="Olan Soule">
       Olan Soule
      </a>
      was the voice of Batman in all these series, but was eventually replaced during
      <i>
       Super Friends
      </i>
      by Adam West, who also voiced the character in
      <a href="/wiki/Filmation" title="Filmation">
       Filmation
      </a>
      's 1977 series
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_Adventures_of_Batman" title="The New Adventures of Batman">
        The New Adventures of Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1989,
      <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros." title="Warner Bros.">
       Warner Bros.
      </a>
      released the live-action feature film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(1989_film)" title="Batman (1989 film)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      ; directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Burton" title="Tim Burton">
       Tim Burton
      </a>
      and starring
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Keaton" title="Michael Keaton">
       Michael Keaton
      </a>
      as the title character. The film was a huge success; not only was it the top-grossing film of the year, but at the time was the fifth highest-grossing film in history.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148">
       <a href="#cite_note-148">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        148
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The film also won the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Art_Direction" title="Academy Award for Best Art Direction">
       Academy Award for Best Art Direction
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        149
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The film's success spawned three sequels:
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Returns" title="Batman Returns">
        Batman Returns
       </a>
      </i>
      (1992),
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Forever" title="Batman Forever">
        Batman Forever
       </a>
      </i>
      (1995) and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_%26_Robin_(film)" title="Batman &amp; Robin (film)">
        Batman &amp; Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      (1997); the latter two of which were directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Joel_Schumacher" title="Joel Schumacher">
       Joel Schumacher
      </a>
      instead of Burton, and replaced Keaton as Batman with
      <a href="/wiki/Val_Kilmer" title="Val Kilmer">
       Val Kilmer
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/George_Clooney" title="George Clooney">
       George Clooney
      </a>
      , respectively. The second Schumacher film, while a box office success, failed to outgross any of its predecessors and was critically panned, causing Warner Bros. to cancel the planned
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_in_film#Batman_Triumphant" title="Batman in film">
        Batman Triumphant
       </a>
      </i>
      sequel and place the
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_in_film" title="Batman in film">
       film series
      </a>
      on hiatus.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batmananimated32.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="203" data-file-width="263" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f3/Batmananimated32.png/220px-Batmananimated32.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/f/f3/Batmananimated32.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/f/f3/Batmananimated32.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batmananimated32.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Batman's appearance in
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Animated_Series" title="Batman: The Animated Series">
          Batman: The Animated Series
         </a>
        </i>
        (199295)
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1992,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Animated_Series" title="Batman: The Animated Series">
        Batman: The Animated Series
       </a>
      </i>
      premiered on the
      <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">
       Fox
      </a>
      television network; produced by
      <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Animation" title="Warner Bros. Animation">
       Warner Bros. Animation
      </a>
      and featuring
      <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Conroy" title="Kevin Conroy">
       Kevin Conroy
      </a>
      as the voice of Batman. The series went on to receive considerable acclaim for its darker tone, mature storytelling, stylistic design and thematic complexity compared to previous superhero cartoons,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
       <a href="#cite_note-150">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        150
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
       <a href="#cite_note-151">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        151
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      in addition to winning multiple
      <a href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">
       Emmy Awards
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        152
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The series' success led to the theatrical film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Mask_of_the_Phantasm" title="Batman: Mask of the Phantasm">
        Batman: Mask of the Phantasm
       </a>
      </i>
      (1993),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
       <a href="#cite_note-153">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        153
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      as well as various
      <a href="/wiki/DC_animated_universe" title="DC animated universe">
       spin-off
      </a>
      TV series; including
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Superman:_The_Animated_Series" title="Superman: The Animated Series">
        Superman: The Animated Series
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_Batman_Adventures" title="The New Batman Adventures">
        The New Batman Adventures
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Justice_League_(TV_series)" title="Justice League (TV series)">
        Justice League
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Justice_League_Unlimited" title="Justice League Unlimited">
        Justice League Unlimited
       </a>
      </i>
      (each of which also featured Conroy as Batman). The futuristic series
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Beyond" title="Batman Beyond">
        Batman Beyond
       </a>
      </i>
      also took place in this same animated continuity and featured a newer, younger
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_(Terry_McGinnis)" title="Batman (Terry McGinnis)">
       Batman
      </a>
      voiced by
      <a href="/wiki/Will_Friedle" title="Will Friedle">
       Will Friedle
      </a>
      . In 2004, a new animated series titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Batman_(TV_series)" title="The Batman (TV series)">
        The Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      made its debut with
      <a href="/wiki/Rino_Romano" title="Rino Romano">
       Rino Romano
      </a>
      as the title character. In 2008, this show was replaced by another animated series,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_The_Brave_and_the_Bold" title="Batman: The Brave and the Bold">
        Batman: The Brave and the Bold
       </a>
      </i>
      , with
      <a href="/wiki/Diedrich_Bader" title="Diedrich Bader">
       Diedrich Bader
      </a>
      as Batman. In 2013, a new
      <a href="/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery" title="Computer-generated imagery">
       CGI
      </a>
      -animated series titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Beware_the_Batman" title="Beware the Batman">
        Beware the Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      made its debut, but was cancelled after one season.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
       <a href="#cite_note-154">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        154
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 2005,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Begins" title="Batman Begins">
        Batman Begins
       </a>
      </i>
      was released to theaters as a
      <a href="/wiki/Reboot_(fiction)" title="Reboot (fiction)">
       reboot
      </a>
      of the Warner Bros. film series; directed by
      <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nolan" title="Christopher Nolan">
       Christopher Nolan
      </a>
      and starring
      <a href="/wiki/Christian_Bale" title="Christian Bale">
       Christian Bale
      </a>
      as Batman. Its sequel,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_(film)" title="The Dark Knight (film)">
        The Dark Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      (2008), set the record for the highest grossing opening weekend of all time in the U.S., earning approximately $158 million,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        155
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and became the fastest film to reach the $400 million mark in the history of American cinema (eighteenth day of release).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        156
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      These record breaking attendances saw
      <i>
       The Dark Knight
      </i>
      end its run as the second-highest domestic grossing film (at the time) with $533 million, bested then only by
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">
        Titanic
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        157
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The film also won two Academy Awards, including
      <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor" title="Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor">
       Best Supporting Actor
      </a>
      for the late
      <a href="/wiki/Heath_Ledger" title="Heath Ledger">
       Heath Ledger
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
       <a href="#cite_note-158">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        158
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was eventually followed by another sequel,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_Rises" title="The Dark Knight Rises">
        The Dark Knight Rises
       </a>
      </i>
      (2012), which served as a conclusion to Nolan's film series. In 2013, Warner Bros. announced that
      <a href="/wiki/Ben_Affleck" title="Ben Affleck">
       Ben Affleck
      </a>
      will be portraying Batman in the upcoming
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Man_of_Steel_(film)" title="Man of Steel (film)">
        Man of Steel
       </a>
      </i>
      sequel
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_v_Superman:_Dawn_of_Justice" title="Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice">
        Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
       <a href="#cite_note-159">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        159
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Batman has also starred in multiple video games, most of which were adaptations of the various cinematic or animated incarnations of the character. Among the most successful of these was
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Arkham_Asylum" title="Batman: Arkham Asylum">
        Batman: Arkham Asylum
       </a>
      </i>
      (2009), which was released by
      <a href="/wiki/Rocksteady_Studios" title="Rocksteady Studios">
       Rocksteady Studios
      </a>
      to critical acclaim; review aggregator
      <a href="/wiki/Metacritic" title="Metacritic">
       Metacritic
      </a>
      reports it as having received 92% positive reviews.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
       <a href="#cite_note-160">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        160
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was followed by the sequel
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Arkham_City" title="Batman: Arkham City">
        Batman: Arkham City
       </a>
      </i>
      (2011), which also received widespread acclaim and holds a Metacritic ranking of 94%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
       <a href="#cite_note-161">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        161
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A prequel game titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Arkham_Origins" title="Batman: Arkham Origins">
        Batman: Arkham Origins
       </a>
      </i>
      (2013) was later released by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Games" title="Warner Bros. Games">
       Warner Bros. Games Montreal
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
       <a href="#cite_note-162">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        162
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A fourth game titled
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman:_Arkham_Knight" title="Batman: Arkham Knight">
        Batman: Arkham Knight
       </a>
      </i>
      is currently scheduled to be released in 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        163
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As with most animated Batman media, Kevin Conroy has provided the voice of the character for these games (except for
      <i>
       Arkham Origins
      </i>
      ).
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Gay_interpretations">
       Gay interpretations
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Homosexuality_in_the_Batman_franchise" title="Homosexuality in the Batman franchise">
       Homosexuality in the Batman franchise
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Batbed.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="256" data-file-width="300" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/7/77/Batbed.png" width="300"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Batbed.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Bruce Wayne and Dick Grayson  panel from
        <i>
         Batman
        </i>
        #84 (June 1954), page 24
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Controversy has arisen over various sexual interpretations made regarding the content of Batman comics in the early decades. Gay interpretations have been part of the academic study of Batman since psychologist
      <a href="/wiki/Fredric_Wertham" title="Fredric Wertham">
       Fredric Wertham
      </a>
      asserted in his
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Seduction_of_the_Innocent" title="Seduction of the Innocent">
        Seduction of the Innocent
       </a>
      </i>
      in 1954 that "Batman stories are psychologically homosexual." He claimed, "The Batman type of story may stimulate children to homosexual
      <a href="/wiki/Sexual_fantasy" title="Sexual fantasy">
       fantasies
      </a>
      , of the nature of which they may be unconscious." Wertham wrote, "Only someone ignorant of the fundamentals of psychiatry and of the
      <a href="/wiki/Psychopathology" title="Psychopathology">
       psychopathology
      </a>
      of sex can fail to realize a subtle atmosphere of
      <a href="/wiki/Homoeroticism" title="Homoeroticism">
       homoeroticism
      </a>
      which pervades the adventures of the mature 'Batman' and his young friend 'Robin.'"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        164
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Andy Medhurst wrote in his 1991 essay "Batman, Deviance, and Camp" that Batman is interesting to gay audiences because "he was one of the first fictional characters to be attacked on the grounds of his presumed homosexuality," "the 1960s TV series remains a touchstone of camp," and "[he] merits analysis as a notably successful construction of masculinity."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
       <a href="#cite_note-165">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        165
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Creators associated with the character have expressed their own opinions. Writer Alan Grant has stated, "The Batman I wrote for 13 years isn't gay. Denny O'Neil's Batman,
      <a href="/wiki/Marv_Wolfman" title="Marv Wolfman">
       Marv Wolfman
      </a>
      's Batman, everybody's Batman all the way back to Bob Kane... none of them wrote him as a gay character. Only Joel Schumacher might have had an opposing view." Writer
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Devin_Grayson" title="Devin Grayson">
       Devin Grayson
      </a>
      has commented, "It depends who you ask, doesn't it? Since you're asking me, I'll say no, I don't think he is ... I certainly understand the gay readings, though."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        166
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      While Frank Miller has described the relationship between Batman and the Joker as a "
      <a href="/wiki/Homophobia" title="Homophobia">
       homophobic
      </a>
      nightmare,"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        167
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      he views the character as
      <a href="/wiki/Sublimation_(psychology)" title="Sublimation (psychology)">
       sublimating
      </a>
      his sexual urges into crimefighting, concluding, "He'd be
      <i>
       much
      </i>
      healthier if he were gay."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
       <a href="#cite_note-168">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        168
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Burt_Ward" title="Burt Ward">
       Burt Ward
      </a>
      , who portrayed Robin in the 1960s television show, has also remarked upon this interpretation in his autobiography
      <i>
       Boy Wonder: My Life in Tights
      </i>
      ; he writes that the relationship could be interpreted as a sexual one, with the show's
      <a href="/wiki/Double_entendre" title="Double entendre">
       double entendres
      </a>
      and lavish camp also possibly offering ambiguous interpretation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        169
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Such gay interpretations continue to attract attention. One notable example occurred in 2000, when DC Comics refused to allow permission for the reprinting of four panels (from
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #79, 92, 105 and 139) to illustrate Christopher York's paper
      <i>
       All in the Family: Homophobia and Batman Comics in the 1950s
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        170
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Another happened in the summer of 2005, when painter Mark Chamberlain displayed a number of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Watercolor" title="Watercolor">
       watercolors
      </a>
      depicting both Batman and Robin in suggestive and sexually explicit poses.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        171
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      DC threatened both artist and the Kathleen Cullen Fine Arts gallery with legal action if they did not cease selling the works and demanded all remaining art, as well as any profits derived from them.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        172
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Will_Brooker" title="Will Brooker">
       Will Brooker
      </a>
      argues in
      <i>
       Batman Unmasked: Analyzing a Cultural Icon
      </i>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
       <a href="#cite_note-173">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        173
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      that a queer reading of
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      is a valid interpretation, and that gay readers would naturally find themselves drawn to the lifestyle depicted within, whether the character of Bruce Wayne himself is explicitly gay or not. He also identifies a homophobic element to the vigour with which mainstream fandom rejects the possibility of a gay reading of the character. In the April 2012 issue of
      <a href="/wiki/Playboy" title="Playboy">
       Playboy
      </a>
      , long time Batman writer
      <a href="/wiki/Grant_Morrison" title="Grant Morrison">
       Grant Morrison
      </a>
      said that "Gayness is built into Batman. I'm not using gay in the pejorative sense, but Batman is very, very gay. There's just no denying it. Obviously as a fictional character he's intended to be heterosexual, but the basis of the whole concept is utterly gay. I think that's why people like it. All these women fancy him and they all wear fetish clothes and jump around rooftops to get to him. He doesn't carehe's more interested in hanging out with the old guy and the kid."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        174
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Building on this, a Comics Alliance opinion piece titled
      <i>
       The Gayness of Batman
      </i>
      discussed the question of gay readings of the character, citing his relationship with the flamboyant Joker as "a monstrous distortion of the conflict between the closet and the scene."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
       <a href="#cite_note-175">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        175
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">
       See also
      </span>
     </h2>

               </a>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="reflist references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 20em; -webkit-column-width: 20em; column-width: 20em; list-style-type: decimal;">
      <ol class="references">

       </li>

        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-3">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

          </a>

        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <i>

         </i>
         (vol. 1) #846 (September 2008)
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-4">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-4">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Silver_Age_(DC_Comics)" title="Silver Age (DC Comics)">
           Silver Age 80-Page Giant
          </a>
         </i>
         #1 (July 2000)
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-Fleisher-5">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-Fleisher_5-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Fleisher_5-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-Fleisher_5-2">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             c
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Fleisher, Michael L.
         <i>
          The Encyclopedia of Comic Book Heroes Volume 1 Batman
         </i>
         Collier Books 1976

       <li id="cite_note-51">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-51">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <span class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20090201081512/http://www.scifi.com:80/scifiwire/index.php?category=5&amp;id=40748" rel="nofollow">
           "Batman Artist Rogers is Dead"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           SciFi Wire
          </i>
          . March 28, 2007. Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.scifi.com/scifiwire/index.php?category=5&amp;id=40748" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>
          on 2009-02-01
         </span>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABatman&amp;rft.atitle=Batman+Artist+Rogers+is+Dead&amp;rft.date=March+28%2C+2007&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.scifi.com%2Fscifiwire%2Findex.php%3Fcategory%3D5%26id%3D40748&amp;rft.jtitle=SciFi+Wire&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         : "Even though their Batman run was only six issues, the three laid the foundation for later Batman comics. Their stories include the classic 'Laughing Fish' (in which the Joker's face appeared on fish); they were adapted for
         <i>
          Batman: The Animated Series
         </i>
         in the 1990s. Earlier drafts of the 1989 Batman movie with Michael Keaton as the Dark Knight were based heavily on their work."
        </span>
       </li>

       <li id="cite_note-pearson_pg_186-66">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>

         <a href="#cite_ref-pearson_pg_186_66-1">
          <sup>
           <i>

           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABatman&amp;rft.aufirst=Travis&amp;rft.au=Langley%2C+Travis&amp;rft.aulast=Langley&amp;rft.btitle=Batman+and+Psychology%3A+A+Dark+and+Stormy+Knight&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=179&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="References">
       References

       <li>
        <span class="citation book">
         Beatty, Scott (2005).
         <i>
          The Batman Handbook: The Ultimate Training Manual
         </i>
         . Quirk Books.
         <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
          ISBN
         </a>
         <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59474-023-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59474-023-7">
          978-1-59474-023-7
         </a>
         .
        </span>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABatman&amp;rft.au=Beatty%2C+Scott&amp;rft.aufirst=Scott&amp;rft.aulast=Beatty&amp;rft.btitle=The+Batman+Handbook%3A+The+Ultimate+Training+Manual&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59474-023-7&amp;rft.pub=Quirk+Books&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

        </span>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Les_Daniels" title="Les Daniels">
         Daniels, Les
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         Batman: The Complete History
        </i>
        . Chronicle Books, 1999.
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780811824705">
         ISBN 978-0-8118-2470-5
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Daniels, Les.
        <i>
         DC Comics: Sixty Years of the World's Favorite Comic Book Heroes
        </i>
        . Bulfinch, 1995.
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780821220764">
         ISBN 978-0-8212-2076-4
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Gerard_Jones" title="Gerard Jones">
         Jones, Gerard
        </a>
        .
        <i>
         Men of Tomorrow: Geeks, Gangsters, and the Birth of the Comic Book
        </i>
        . Basic Books, 1995.
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780465036578">
         ISBN 978-0-465-03657-8
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Pearson, Roberta E.; Uricchio, William (editors).
        <i>
         The Many Lives of the Batman: Critical Approaches to a Superhero and His Media
        </i>
        . Routledge: London, 1991.
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780851702766">
         ISBN 978-0-85170-276-6
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        Wright, Bradford W.
        <i>
         Comic Book Nation: The Transformation of Youth Culture in America
        </i>
        . The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2001.
        <a class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn" href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780801865145">
         ISBN 978-0-8018-6514-5
        </a>
        .
       </li>
      </ul>
     </div>

                <tr>
                 <th class="navbox-group" scope="row">
                  Storylines
                 </th>
                 <td class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px;">
                  <div style="padding:0em 0.25em;">
                   <ul>
                    <li>
                     "
                     <a href="/wiki/The_Case_of_the_Chemical_Syndicate" title="The Case of the Chemical Syndicate">
                      The Case of the Chemical Syndicate
                     </a>
                     "
                    </li>
                    <li>
                     "
                     <a href="/wiki/The_Man_Behind_the_Red_Hood!" title="The Man Behind the Red Hood!">
                      The Man Behind the Red Hood!
                     </a>
                     "
                    </li>

                  </div>
                  <div style="font-size:110%;">
                   Unauthorized
                   <strong class="selflink">
                    Batman
                   </strong>
                   films
                  </div>
                 </th>
                </tr>

         Lego Batman 2: DC Super Heroes
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      Since his first appearance in 1939,
      <a href="/wiki/Batman" title="Batman">
       Batman
      </a>
      has been adapted into such media as film, radio, television, and video games, as well as numerous merchandising items.
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <p>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Theatrical_films">
       Theatrical films
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Batman_franchise_media&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Theatrical films">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote relarticle mainarticle">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Batman_in_film" title="Batman in film">
       Batman in film
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      A number of Batman theatrical
      <a href="/wiki/Film" title="Film">
       films
      </a>
      have been made. There have also been several attempted projects during the hiatus between
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_%26_Robin_(film)" title="Batman &amp; Robin (film)">
        Batman &amp; Robin
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_Begins" title="Batman Begins">
        Batman Begins
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>

       <i>

        </a>

       </a>
       will play Batman in the film.
