     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_and_work">
       Early life and work
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life and work">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      Robert Kahn was born in
      <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
       New York City
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/New_York" title="New York">
       New York
      </a>
      . His parents, Augusta and Herman Kahn, an engraver,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-1">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        1
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      were of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_European_Jews" title="Eastern European Jews">
       Eastern European Jewish
      </a>
      descent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-2">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        2
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/High_school" title="High school">
       high school
      </a>
      friend of fellow cartoonist and future
      <a href="/wiki/Spirit_(comics)" title="Spirit (comics)">
       Spirit
      </a>
      creator
      <a href="/wiki/Will_Eisner" title="Will Eisner">
       Will Eisner
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UUaOV_3-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UUaOV-3">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        3
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Robert Kahn graduated from
      <a href="/wiki/DeWitt_Clinton_High_School" title="DeWitt Clinton High School">
       DeWitt Clinton High School
      </a>
      and then legally changed his name to
      <b>
       Bob Kane
      </b>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-me_4-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-me-4">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        4
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He studied art at
      <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union" title="Cooper Union">
       Cooper Union
      </a>
      before "joining the
      <a href="/wiki/Max_Fleischer" title="Max Fleischer">
       Max Fleischer
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Fleischer_Studios" title="Fleischer Studios">
       Studio
      </a>
      as a trainee animator in 1934".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-5">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        5
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Comics">
       Comics
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Comics">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      He entered the comics field two years later, in 1936, freelancing original material to editor
      <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Iger" title="Jerry Iger">
       Jerry Iger
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_book" title="Comic book">
       comic book
      </a>
      <i>
       Wow, What A Magazine!
      </i>
      , including his first pencil and ink work on the serial
      <i>
       Hiram Hick
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223_6-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      The following year, Kane began to work at Iger's subsequent studio,
      <a href="/wiki/Eisner_%26_Iger" title="Eisner &amp; Iger">
       Eisner &amp; Iger
      </a>
      , which was one of the first comic book "packagers" that produced comics on demand for publishers entering the new
      <a href="/wiki/Mass_media" title="Mass media">
       medium
      </a>
      during its late-1930s and 1940s
      <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Comic_Books" title="Golden Age of Comic Books">
       Golden Age
      </a>
      . Among his work there was the
      <a href="/wiki/Funny_animal" title="Funny animal">
       funny animal
      </a>
      feature "Peter Pupp"  which belied its look with overtones of "mystery and menace"
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
       published in the U.K. comic magazine
      <i>
       Wags
      </i>
      and reprinted in
      <a href="/wiki/Fiction_House" title="Fiction House">
       Fiction House
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jumbo_comics" title="Jumbo comics">
        Jumbo comics
       </a>
      </i>
      . Kane also produced work through Eisner &amp; Iger for two of the companies that would later merge to form DC Comics, including the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Humor" title="Humor">
       humor
      </a>
      features "Ginger Snap" in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/More_Fun_Comics" title="More Fun Comics">
        More Fun Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      , "Oscar the Gumshoe" for
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Detective_Comics" title="Detective Comics">
        Detective Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      , and "Professor Doolittle" for
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Adventure_Comics" title="Adventure Comics">
        Adventure Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      . For that last title he went on to do his first adventure strip, "Rusty and his Pals".
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Batman">
       Batman
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Batman">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Detective_Comics_27.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="419" data-file-width="300" height="251" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a8/Detective_Comics_27.jpg/180px-Detective_Comics_27.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a8/Detective_Comics_27.jpg/270px-Detective_Comics_27.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a8/Detective_Comics_27.jpg 2x" width="180"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Detective_Comics_27.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <i>
         Detective Comics
        </i>
        #27 (May 1939). The first appearance of Batman. Art by Bob Kane.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In early 1939, DC's success with the seminal superhero
      <a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">
       Superman
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Action_Comics" title="Action Comics">
        Action Comics
       </a>
      </i>
      prompted editors to scramble for more such heroes. In response, Bob Kane conceived "the Bat-Man."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
       <a href="#cite_note-7">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        7
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Kane said his influences for the character included actor
      <a href="/wiki/Douglas_Fairbanks" title="Douglas Fairbanks">
       Douglas Fairbanks
      </a>
      ' movie portrayal of the
      <a href="/wiki/Swashbuckler" title="Swashbuckler">
       swashbuckler
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Zorro" title="Zorro">
       Zorro
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">
       Leonardo da Vinci
      </a>
      's diagram of the
      <a href="/wiki/Ornithopter" title="Ornithopter">
       ornithopter
      </a>
      , a flying machine with huge bat-like wings; and the 1930 film
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Bat_(1926_film)#Remakes" title="The Bat (1926 film)">
        The Bat Whispers
       </a>
      </i>
      , based on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mary_Rinehart" title="Mary Rinehart">
       Mary Rinehart
      </a>
      's mystery novel
      <i>
       The Circular Staircase
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
       <a href="#cite_note-8">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        8
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Bill_Finger" title="Bill Finger">
       Bill Finger
      </a>
      joined Bob Kane's nascent studio in 1938. An aspiring writer and part-time shoe salesperson, he had met Kane at a party, and Kane later offered him a job
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ghost_writer" title="Ghost writer">
       ghost writing
      </a>
      the strips
      <i>
       Rusty
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       Clip Carson
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        9
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jim_10-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-jim-10">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        10
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      He recalled that Kane
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       ...had an idea for a character called 'Batman', and he'd like me to see the drawings. I went over to Kane's, and he had drawn a character who looked very much like Superman with kind of ... reddish tights, I believe, with boots ... no gloves, no gauntlets ... with a small domino mask, swinging on a rope. He had two stiff wings that were sticking out, looking like bat wings. And under it was a big sign ... BATMAN.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jim_10-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-jim-10">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         10
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="401" data-file-width="450" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg/200px-Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg/300px-Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg/400px-Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Awest_bkane_fgorshin_1966.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Adam_West" title="Adam West">
         Adam West
        </a>
        , Bob Kane and
        <a href="/wiki/Frank_Gorshin" title="Frank Gorshin">
         Frank Gorshin
        </a>
        on the set of the 1960s TV show
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Batman_(TV_series)" title="Batman (TV series)">
          Batman
         </a>
        </i>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Finger said he offered such suggestions as giving the character a cowl and scalloped cape instead of wings; adding gloves; leaving the mask's eyeholes blank to connote mystery; and removing the bright red sections of the original costume, suggesting instead a gray-and-black color scheme. Finger additionally said
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
       <a href="#cite_note-11">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        11
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      his suggestions were influenced by
      <a href="/wiki/Lee_Falk" title="Lee Falk">
       Lee Falk
      </a>
      's
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Phantom" title="The Phantom">
        The Phantom
       </a>
      </i>
      , a
      <a href="/wiki/Print_syndication" title="Print syndication">
       syndicated
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Newspaper" title="Newspaper">
       newspaper
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">
       comic strip
      </a>
      character with which Kane was familiar as well. Finger, who said he also devised the character's civilian name,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bruce_Wayne" title="Bruce Wayne">
       Bruce Wayne
      </a>
      , wrote the first Batman story, while Kane provided art. Kane, who had already submitted the proposal for Batman at DC and held a contract, is the only person given official company credit for Batman's creation. Comics historian
      <a href="/wiki/Ron_Goulart" title="Ron Goulart">
       Ron Goulart
      </a>
      , in
      <i>
       Comic Book Encyclopedia
      </i>
      , refers to Batman as the "creation of artist Bob Kane and writer Bill Finger".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
       <a href="#cite_note-12">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        12
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      According to Kane, "Bill Finger was a contributing force on Batman right from the beginning. He wrote most of the great stories and was influential in setting the style and genre other writers would emulate ... I made Batman a superhero-vigilante when I first created him. Bill turned him into a scientific detective.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
       <a href="#cite_note-13">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        13
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The character debuted in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #27 (May 1939) and proved a breakout hit. Within a year, Kane hired art assistants
      <a href="/wiki/Jerry_Robinson" title="Jerry Robinson">
       Jerry Robinson
      </a>
      (initially as an
      <a href="/wiki/Inker" title="Inker">
       inker
      </a>
      ) and
      <a href="/wiki/George_Roussos" title="George Roussos">
       George Roussos
      </a>
      (backgrounds artist and
      <a href="/wiki/Letterer" title="Letterer">
       letterer
      </a>
      ). Though Robinson and Roussos worked out of Kane's art studio in
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">
        The New York Times
       </a>
      </i>
      building, Kane himself did all his drawing at home.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14">
       <a href="#cite_note-14">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        14
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Shortly afterward, when DC wanted more Batman stories than Kane's studio could deliver, the company assigned
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Sprang" title="Dick Sprang">
       Dick Sprang
      </a>
      and other in-house pencilers as "
      <a href="/wiki/Ghostwriter" title="Ghostwriter">
       ghost artists
      </a>
      ", drawing uncredited under Kane's supervision. Future
      <i>
       Justice League
      </i>
      writer
      <a href="/wiki/Gardner_Fox" title="Gardner Fox">
       Gardner Fox
      </a>
      wrote some early scripts, including the two-part story "The Monk" that introduced some of The Batman's first "Bat-" equipment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
       <a href="#cite_note-15">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        15
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1943, Kane left the Batman comic books to focus on penciling the daily
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      newspaper
      <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">
       comic strip
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223_6-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      DC Comics artists ghosting the comic-book stories now included
      <a href="/wiki/Jack_Burnley" title="Jack Burnley">
       Jack Burnley
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Win_Mortimer" title="Win Mortimer">
       Win Mortimer
      </a>
      , with Robinson moving up as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Penciler" title="Penciler">
       penciler
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Fred_Ray" title="Fred Ray">
       Fred Ray
      </a>
      contributing some covers. After the strip finished in 1946, Kane returned to the comic books but, unknown to DC, had hired his own personal ghosts, including
      <a href="/wiki/Lew_Schwartz" title="Lew Schwartz">
       Lew Schwartz
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223_6-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Joe_Desris_1994_p._223-6">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        6
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Sheldon_Moldoff" title="Sheldon Moldoff">
       Sheldon Moldoff
      </a>
      from 1953-1967.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
       <a href="#cite_note-16">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        16
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Robin">
       Robin
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Robin">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Bill Finger recalled that,
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       "Robin was an outgrowth of a conversation I had with Bob. As I said, Batman was a combination of [Douglas] Fairbanks and Sherlock Holmes. Holmes had his Watson. The thing that bothered me was that Batman didn't have anyone to talk to, and it got a little tiresome always having him thinking. I found that as I went along Batman needed a Watson to talk to. That's how Robin came to be. Bob called me over and said he was going to put a boy in the strip to identify with Batman. I thought it was a great idea."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jim_10-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-jim-10">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         10
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      Kane, who had previously created a sidekick for Peter Pupp, proposed adding a boy named Mercury who would have worn a "super-costume".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
       <a href="#cite_note-17">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        17
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Robinson suggested a normal human, along with the name "
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_(name)" title="Robin (name)">
       Robin
      </a>
      ", after
      <a href="/wiki/Robin_Hood" title="Robin Hood">
       Robin Hood
      </a>
      books he had read during boyhood, and noting in a 2005 interview he had been inspired by one book's
      <a href="/wiki/N._C._Wyeth" title="N. C. Wyeth">
       N. C. Wyeth
      </a>
      illustrations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TCJ271_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TCJ271-18">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        18
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       The impetus came from Bill's wanting to extend the parameters of the story potential and of the drama. He saw that adding a sidekick would enhance the drama. Also, it enlarged the readership identification. The younger kids could then identify with Robin, which they couldn't with Batman, and the older ones with Batman. It extended the appeal on a lot of levels.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TCJ271_18-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-TCJ271-18">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         18
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      The new character, orphaned circus performer named
      <a href="/wiki/Dick_Grayson" title="Dick Grayson">
       Dick Grayson
      </a>
      , came to live with Bruce Wayne as his young
      <a href="/wiki/Ward_(law)" title="Ward (law)">
       ward
      </a>
      in
      <i>
       Detective Comics
      </i>
      #38 (April 1940) and would inspire many similar sidekicks throughout the Golden Age of comic books.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="The_Joker">
       The Joker
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: The Joker">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Batman's nemesis the
      <a href="/wiki/Joker_(comics)" title="Joker (comics)">
       Joker
      </a>
      was introduced near that same time, in
      <i>
       Batman
      </i>
      #1 (Spring 1940). Credit for that character's creation is disputed. Kane's position is that
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       "Bill Finger and I created the Joker. Bill was the writer. Jerry Robinson came to me with a playing card of the Joker. That's the way I sum it up. [The Joker] looks like
       <a href="/wiki/Conrad_Veidt" title="Conrad Veidt">
        Conrad Veidt
       </a>
        you know, the actor in
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Man_Who_Laughs_(1928_film)" title="The Man Who Laughs (1928 film)">
         The Man Who Laughs
        </a>
       </i>
       , [the 1928 movie based on the novel] by
       <a href="/wiki/Victor_Hugo" title="Victor Hugo">
        Victor Hugo
       </a>
       . ... Bill Finger had a book with a photograph of Conrad Veidt and showed it to me and said, 'Here's the Joker'. Jerry Robinson had absolutely nothing to do with it. But he'll always say he created it till he dies. He brought in a
       <a href="/wiki/Playing_card" title="Playing card">
        playing card
       </a>
       , which we used for a couple of issues for him [the Joker] to use as his playing card".
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         19
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      Robinson, whose original Joker playing card was on public display in the exhibition "Masters of American Comics" at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Museum_(New_York)" title="Jewish Museum (New York)">
       Jewish Museum
      </a>
      in New York City, New York, from September 16, 2006 to January 28, 2007, and the William Breman Jewish Heritage Museum in
      <a href="/wiki/Atlanta" title="Atlanta">
       Atlanta
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">
       Georgia
      </a>
      from October 24, 2004 to August 28, 2005, has countered that:
     </p>
     <blockquote class="templatequote">
      <p>
       Bill Finger knew of Conrad Veidt because Bill had been to a lot of the foreign films. Veidt ... had this clown makeup with the frozen smile on his face (classic). When Bill saw the first drawing of the Joker, he said, 'That reminds me of Conrad Veidt in
       <i>
        The Man Who Laughs
       </i>
       .' He said he would bring in some shots of that movie to show me. That's how that came about. I think in Bill's mind, he fleshed out the concept of the character.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         <span>
          [
         </span>
         20
         <span>
          ]
         </span>
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
     </blockquote>
     <p>
      Robinson added, however, that Finger "can be credited and Bob himself, we all played a role in it....He wrote the script of that, so he really was co-creator, and Bob and I did the visuals, so Bob was also.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        21
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_characters">
       Other characters
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Other characters">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      According to comics historian
      <a href="/wiki/Les_Daniels" title="Les Daniels">
       Les Daniels
      </a>
      , "nearly everyone seems to agree that
      <a href="/wiki/Two-Face" title="Two-Face">
       Two-Face
      </a>
      was Kane's brainchild exclusively".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        22
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Catwoman" title="Catwoman">
       Catwoman
      </a>
      , originally introduced by Kane with no costume as "the Cat", was partially inspired by his cousin, Ruth Steel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23">
       <a href="#cite_note-23">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        23
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        24
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Kane, a frequent movie goer, mentioned that
      <a href="/wiki/Jean_Harlow" title="Jean Harlow">
       Jean Harlow
      </a>
      was a model for the design and added that "I always felt that women were feline".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daniels.2C_Les_1999.2C_p._42_25-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Daniels.2C_Les_1999.2C_p._42-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Kane created the
      <a href="/wiki/Scarecrow_(DC_Comics)" title="Scarecrow (DC Comics)">
       Scarecrow
      </a>
      and drew his first appearance, which was scripted by Finger.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        26
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Kane also created the original incarnation of
      <a href="/wiki/Clayface" title="Clayface">
       Clayface
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        27
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to Kane, he drew
      <a href="/wiki/Penguin_(comics)" title="Penguin (comics)">
       the Penguin
      </a>
      after being inspired by the then advertising mascot of
      <a href="/wiki/Kool_(cigarette)" title="Kool (cigarette)">
       Kool
      </a>
      cigarettes  a
      <a href="/wiki/Penguin" title="Penguin">
       penguin
      </a>
      with a top hat and cane. Finger, however, claimed that he created the villain as a caricature of the aristocratic type, because "stuffy English gentlemen" reminded him of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emperor_penguins" title="Emperor penguins">
       emperor penguins
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daniels.2C_Les_1999.2C_p._42_25-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Daniels.2C_Les_1999.2C_p._42-25">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        25
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        28
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Later_life_and_career">
       Later life and career
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Kane&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Later life and career">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <p>
      In 1966, Kane retired from DC Comics, choosing to focus on fine art.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Park_West_Gallery_29-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Park_West_Gallery-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      As Kane's comic-book work tapered off in the 1960s, he parlayed his Batman status into minor celebrity. He enjoyed a post-comics career in
      <a href="/wiki/Animation_in_the_United_States_in_the_television_era" title="Animation in the United States in the television era">
       TV animation
      </a>
      , creating the characters
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courageous_Cat" title="Courageous Cat">
       Courageous Cat
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cool_McCool" title="Cool McCool">
       Cool McCool
      </a>
      , and as a painter showed his work in
      <a href="/wiki/Art_museum" title="Art museum">
       art galleries
      </a>
      , although some of these paintings were produced by ghost artists.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        30
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      DC Comics named Kane in 1985 as one of the honorees in the company's 50th anniversary publication
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Fifty_Who_Made_DC_Great" title="Fifty Who Made DC Great">
        Fifty Who Made DC Great
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        31
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1989, Kane published the autobiography
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_and_Me" title="Batman and Me">
        Batman and Me
       </a>
      </i>
      , with a second volume
      <i>
       Batman and Me, The Saga Continues
      </i>
      , in 1996.
     </p>
     <p>
      Kane worked as a consultant on the 1989 movie
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Batman_(1989_film)" title="Batman (1989 film)">
        Batman
       </a>
      </i>
      and its three sequels with directors
      <a href="/wiki/Tim_Burton" title="Tim Burton">
       Tim Burton
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Joel_Schumacher" title="Joel Schumacher">
       Joel Schumacher
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Stan_Lee" title="Stan Lee">
       Stan Lee
      </a>
      interviewed Kane in the documentary series
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Comic_Book_Greats" title="The Comic Book Greats">
        The Comic Book Greats
       </a>
      </i>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Kane was inducted into the Jack Kirby Hall of Fame and the WIll Eisner Comic Book Hall of Fame during his lifetime.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Park_West_Gallery_29-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Park_West_Gallery-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Kane died on November 3, 1998, from natural causes, leaving behind his wife, Elizabeth Sanders (Kane), an actress who appeared in three Batman films; and daughter Deborah Majeski.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytobit_32-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nytobit-32">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        32
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      Kane is buried at
      <a href="/wiki/Forest_Lawn_Memorial_Park_(Hollywood_Hills)" title="Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)">
       Forest Lawn - Hollywood Hills Cemetery
      </a>
      in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Los_Angeles,_California" title="Los Angeles, California">
       Los Angeles, California
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        33
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        34
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Kane's work is still visible to the public, housed in collections such as the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City and St. John's University in Jamaica, New York.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Park_West_Gallery_29-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Park_West_Gallery-29">
        <span>
         [
        </span>
        29
        <span>
         ]
        </span>
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>

       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>

        <a href="/wiki/Category:Wikipedia_articles_with_LCCN_identifiers" title="Category:Wikipedia articles with LCCN identifiers">
         Wikipedia articles with LCCN identifiers
        </a>
